Introduction
Hydraulic fracturing techniques have been widely applied in oil/gas extraction, coalbed methane, waste disposal, enhanced geothermal systems, and pre-conditioning ore bodies for block-caving mining, etc.
1–5
 The cased and cemented wellbore is one of the most common types for wells that will facilitate hydraulic fracturing.
6–8
 For a cased and cemented well, perforations are designed to connect the wellbore to the rock formation by punching holes through the casing and cement sheath. The hydraulic fractures that emanate from the cased and cemented well may be tortuous, especially when the perforation orientation is not aligned with the preferred fracture direction (i.e., the direction of the maximum in-situ principal stress). The near-wellbore fracture significantly affects the fluid flow, proppant transportation and well productivity.
9–12
 Therefore, it is crucial to clearly understand the near-wellbore fracturing of rock as it is affected by various underlying factors.
For an open hole well completion, hydraulic fractures are initiated when the hoop tensile stress around the wellbore exceeds the tensile strength of the rock and propagate along the maximum principal stress direction. In this case, the fracture initiation pressure can be determined by the in-situ stress, rock strength and pore pressure, which has also been widely used for the in-situ stress measurement in hydraulic fracturing.
13
 Further, Hossain et al.
14
 developed an analytical model to determine the fracture initiation pressure for an open wellbore with perforation and found that the perforation invariably reduced the fracture initiation pressure when the perforations were oriented along the preferred fracture direction; however, when the perforation were created and deviated away from the preferred direction, a higher breakdown pressure was needed.
Open hole well completion has considerable limitation in conducting stimulation especially in medium- and low-permeability reservoirs. Casing perforation completion has therefore been widely adopted to help with various downhole operations especially where borehole stability is an issue. For a cased and cemented well, the combined casing-cement-rock structure will influence and, in some sense, control the pressure acting on the rock. Yew et al.
15

,

16
 derived an analytical solution to determine fracture initiation pressure for a cased well and found that the steel casing had a dominant effect on the stress distribution around the wellbore and that the hoop stress of rock for a cased well is larger than that for an open hole. Zhu et al.
6
 developed an analytical model to predict the fracture initiation pressure for a cased well with perforation and postulated that the fracture initiation pressure is more accurate when considering the casing structure. Dong et al.
17
 proposed a theoretical model based on Mode I and Model II Stress Intensity Factors (SIF) to determine the critical water pressure and the critical initiation angle for hydraulic fracturing through a single radial perforation emanating from a borehole and found the fracture initiation angle decreased with the increase of the water injection pressure. However, the existing models
6

,

15

,

16
 assumed that the elastic modulus of cement was the same as that of rock and the effect of the cement sheath on fracturing was not considered. Moreover, the fracture tortuosity and propagation pressure for the cased and cemented well with perforations are extremely hard to determine by analytical methods.
In the past few decades, the near-wellbore rock fracturing problem has been investigated by a number of researchers, particularly with numerical methods.
9

,

10

,

18–20
 Zhang et al.
10
 developed a coupled numerical model for rock deformation and fluid flow to simulate near-wellbore hydraulic fracturing and found that using more viscous fluid and higher injection rates can reduce near-wellbore fracture tortuosity. He et al.
20
 employed the discrete finite element method (Universal Distinct Element Code) to simulate the hydraulic fracture re-orientation around the wellbore with a perforation or flaw. They found that hydraulic fracture tended to be oriented by perforations in relatively heterogeneous rocks. Cherny et al.
18
 developed a finite element method to model the near-wellbore fracture propagation by predetermining a curving fracture following an arc with a given radius. Xiang et al.
21
 simulated fracture initiation from a wellbore and propagation in a rock formation with pre-existing fractures by inserting cohesive elements into the edges of bulk elements. Dong and Tang
11
 first proposed a SIF-based incremental crack growth method to model the near-wellbore hydraulic fracture propagation and comprehensively discussed the effects of perforations angles, lengths and stress ratios on the fracture trajectory. They found that the perforation angle was the most important controlling factor in complicating the hydraulic fracture propagation path near-the wellbore.
11
 However, modelling the arbitrary cracking of rock is quite cumbersome or time-consuming for continuously remeshing around the new crack tip or embedding interface elements into the edges of the solid elements.
The extended finite element method (XFEM) can provide an effective tool in solving the technical issues associated with modelling arbitrary cracking and hence is ideal in simulating the near-well rock fracture tortuosity. Li et al.
22
 simulated the re-orientation of hydraulic fractures using XFEM and found a larger perforation angle (angle between the perforation and the in-situ maximum principal stress) resulted in a more curving fracture path. Feng and Gray
9

,

19
 modelled the fracture propagation from the wellbore in XFEM and discussed the effects of multiple perforation designs on the fracturing process. Further, considering rock as permeable medium with Mohr-Coulomb plasticity, Wang
23
 developed a fully coupled XFEM model to simulate non-planar hydraulic fracture propagation. However, in almost all the existing models for near-wellbore hydraulic fracturing, the pressure acting on the rock surface of the wellbore (the actual pressure transmitted to the formation) was assumed to be the same as the casing fluid pressure. This is an unrealistic hypothesis as it ignores the deformation and load-transferring capacity of the composite well system. To date, there is no model which accounts for the realistic pressure on the wellbore surface and which can therefore reliably simulate the near-wellbore rock fracture propagation, for cased and perforated wells. This poses challenges in accurately modelling the near-wellbore fracture tortuosity in rock and optimization of the perforated completion.
This paper develops a combined analytical-numerical method to simulate the near-wellbore rock fracture initiation and propagation for a cased and cemented well with perforations. An analytical model is first derived for calculating the pressure acting on the rock surface with the consideration of stress transmission through the casing-cement-rock structure. The effects of geometries (i.e., thicknesses of casing and cement sheath) and mechanical properties (i.e., Young's modulus of casing and cement) on the pressure transmission are explored through the analytical model. Based on the XFEM framework and cohesive crack model, the near-wellbore fracture of rock is simulated and analysed. The pressure applied on the wellbore rock surface is correlated with the casing injection pressure by the developed analytical transmission equation through an in-house ABAQUS subroutine written in FORTRAN. A worked example is then presented to demonstrate the application of the combined analytical-numerical method. Model verification is also conducted by comparing the results with those from experiments. Furthermore, a deflection angle is defined to quantitatively describe the near-wellbore fracture tortuosity. A parametric study is carried out to discuss the effects of some underlying parameters, e.g., pressure transmission coefficient, perforation angle, in-situ stress field, and perforation depth, on the development of injection pressure, fracture trajectory and deflection angle.


2
Analytical formulation for the pressure transmission through the casing-cementing-rock system

2.1
Model description

Fig. 1
 illustrates a vertical well system with steel casing, cement sheath, rock formation and perforations. In the cased, cemented and perforated well, fluid injected into the casing produces pressure and fractures the rock. Due to the uniform strain along the well axial direction, the deformation of the casing-cement-rock structure can be regarded as a plane strain problem.
6

,

24

,

25
 The radial fluid pressure on the inner surface of the casing first deforms the casing and is then transmitted to the cement and rock. The realistic pressure to fracture the rock is therefore not the hydraulic pressure acting on the steel casing, but the pressure transferred through the well system to the rock. Previous studies have only considered the effect of steel casing on the fracture initiation of rock with the assumption that the elastic modulus of the cement sheath is the same as that of the rock
6

,

25
 which can lead to inaccurate calculation of the driving force to fracture the rock. In this study, we consider the three-layer structure of well, consisting of casing, cement sheath and rock, and determine the pressure acting on the cement-rock interface which will be used for modelling the near-wellbore fracture of rock.
The following assumptions are made for the analytical model: (1) the interfaces between casing, cement and rock are perfectly bound together; (2) the steel casing and cement are considered as elastic materials; (3) the near-well cracking of rock will not affect the radial direction elastic modulus of the rock formation, so the rock can still be considered as deforming elastically when determining the pressure transmission and; (4) only the fluid pressure-induced stress in the casing-cement-well system is formulated in the analytical model while the stress induced by the in-situ stress and the hole will be considered and superimposed in the numerical model. Similar assumptions have been made and generally accepted for modelling the effect of casing on hydraulic fracturing.

Thus, a coupled fluid pressure-traction-separation relationship exists between the cohesive zone defined by the stress-displacement law and the lubrication model.
50

,

51





4
Worked example and verification
We first discuss the effect of well system design on the pressure transmission to the rock. The key design parameters for casing and cement to ensure the well integrity include geometric size (i.e., the thickness of casing and cement sheath) and the mechanical properties (e.g., Young's modulus of steel casing and cement).
7
 By using Equations (10) and (11), the effects of these key design parameters of casing and cement on the pressure transmission coefficient to the rock can be assessed. Typical values for these parameters are listed in Table 1
. Fig. 5
 illustrates the effect of thickness of casing and cement on the pressure transmission coefficient. It can be seen that the value for the pressure transmission coefficient K decreases from 0.71 to 0.12 when the casing thickness and cement sheath thickness change from 5 to 55 mm, respectively. In general, the thicker the casing or cement sheath is, the less pressure is transferred to the rock. In particular, the thinner either the casing or the cement sheath, the variation of K caused by the change of the other thickness parameters is larger. For example, when the casing thickness is 30 mm, K varies from 0.08 to 0.19 with cement sheath thickness of 30 mm–10 mm. While for casing thickness of 10 mm, K varies from 0.27 to 0.49 with cement sheath thickness from 30 mm to 10 mm. Fig. 6
 shows the effect of Young's modulus of casing and cement on the pressure transmission coefficient. It is interesting that the larger Young's modulus of the casing, the smaller the pressure transmission coefficient. In contrast, with increasing Young's modulus of cement, the pressure transmission coefficient sharply increases first but keeps almost constant after around 20 GPa. Young's modulus for widely used Class G cement normally varies from 2 to 30 GPa which is related to water/cement ratio, curing time and construction quality, etc.
52
 A lower Young's modulus of cement can reduce the pressure transmitted onto the rock formation. Therefore, the casing and cement sheath have significant effects on the pressure transmission and the cement sheath should be considered in any model to determine the rock fracture initiation or propagation.
As a demonstration of the developed method in solving near-well fracture of rock, a plane strain worked example for a cased and cemented well with a single perforation is presented. The model is a two-dimensional plane strain cylinder with an external radius of 1.5 m which is large enough for modelling the near-wellbore fracture problem. The angle between the maximum principal stress and perforation is 60°. Fig. 7
 shows the mesh of the worked example. To reduce the degrees of freedom for the numerical model and improve the accuracy, the area of interest for potential cracking is meshed with refined elements. There are 77,540 quadratic elements in the whole model with a minimum size of 1 mm which is much smaller than the length of fracture process zone. It should be mentioned that, the realistic perforations are three-dimensional circular holes. This 2D model is just capable to simulate the initiation and propagation of perforated fracture plane outwards the well.
10

,

19
 A 3D fracture modelling based on cohesive crack model is very challenging due to element size requirements, i.e., the element size should be much smaller than the length of fracture process zone. The effects of the 3D perforation slots on the rock cracking are not considered in this model.
The simulation steps used in this study are as follows: first, the geostatic equilibrium status is established after the in-situ stresses and initial pore pressure are applied to the model; second, the elements within the wellbore zone are removed to simulate the wellbore extraction; finally, fluid is injected into the perforation by a concentrated flow at the phantom node of the enriched element nearest the wellbore surface. During the fluid injection process, the pore pressure at the injecting point can be regarded as the fluid pressure in the well. This fluid pressure, varying with the rock fracture, is monitored by a sensor subroutine in ABAQUS solver. The varying pressure is updated and applied on to the rock surface by multiplying the pressure transmission coefficient K with the injection pressure. The coupling process of fluid injection and injection-induced pressure acting on the rock surface is achieved by an in-house ABAQUS subroutine written in FORTRAN. The values and their resources for the basic geometric and mechanical parameters in the worked example are listed in Table 2
. The determined pressure transmission coefficient through Equation (11) is 0.5 in the worked example.

Fig. 8
 illustrates the development of injection pressure as a function of injection time. It can be seen that the injection pressure rapidly increases up to the critical pressure (about 58 MPa) when the rock fracture begins to propagate. Pressure then gradually drops as the fracture propagates, flattening when the fracture propagates to about 0.2 m long (i.e., point B in Fig. 8). After 1.7 s of injection, the fracture length reaches 0.75 m which is about 10 times the well radius. Fig. 9
 shows the pore pressure distributions at the injection time points 0.0016 s, 0.18 s, 0.59 s and 1.43 s, respectively. The injection pressures for these four time points are referred to as points A, B, C, D, respectively, in Fig. 8. It can be seen that the rock fracture initiates at the end of the perforation and propagates within the enriched elements. The pore pressure in the cracked elements for the perforation is larger due to higher permeability. With the injection time increasing, the fracture propagates towards the maximum principal stress direction. A fluid lag zone is seen ahead of the crack tip where the pore pressure is very small. In this fluid lag zone the mesh is open but not pressurised by the fluid: this is an important feature of viscous fluid-driven fracture growth.
10
 With the fracture propagation, the pore pressure beyond the sides of crack is also increased due to fluid leak-off.

Fig. 10
 shows the near-well fracture trajectory and width at the final injection time 1.7 s. It can be seen that the fracture propagates towards the maximum principal stress direction (x direction) at about 0.85 m and 10 times the well radius. The fracture deflection is induced by the in-situ stress difference. The curved fracture can well represent the fracture complexity near the perforated well.
9
 . Moreover, the fracture width at the middle of the fracture is larger while the widths near the perforation and the crack tip are smaller. The restriction of the opening of fracture near the perforation could provide a benefit in plugging lost circulation fractures in wellbore strengthening operations, but would also pose difficulties for proppant placement due to bridging.

To verify the proposed numerical model, the results are compared with experimental data from the literature.

 Abass et al. conducted hydraulic fracturing tests on cuboid blocks of hydrostone (i.e., cement mortar) with perforations and obtained fractures with a curved trajectory.
12
 We establish a 2D plane-strain model with a perforation angle 75° with the dimensions of 152.4 mm × 152.4 mm to verify the developed numerical method. There are 18,496 quadratic elements in the whole model and the mesh is refined around the wellbore. The wellbore has a radius of 9.5 mm and the depth of perforation is 12.7 mm.  shows the mesh grid for verification and the comparisons of fracture trajectory predicted by our numerical approach and the experimental results of Abass et al.
12
 The numerical results for the fracture trajectory are in very good agreement with most of the points obtained from the experimental results, which validates the capability of the developed numerical method. The differences of the deviation the experimental and numerical results on the crack away from the injection hole can be attributed to: (1) the numerical model is simplified from the physical experiments and some experimental conditions are not considered in the numerical model, e.g., friction effects between the loading plates and the specimen surfaces. (2) the numerical model is assumed as homogeneous while the heterogeneity of specimens might cause some differences.


5
Parametric study and discussion
Since the pressure transmission coefficient varies with the casing-cement-rock structure and is often overlooked in modelling, it is necessary to investigate the effect of the pressure transmission coefficient on the injection pressure and fracture trajectory. Fig. 13
 illustrates that the development of wellbore pressure under different values of K, i.e., K = 0.3 to 0.7. The other parameters in the numerical models have been kept the same as those used in the worked example. It is clear that the stress transmission through the well system to the rock significantly affects the pressure development, especially in the early stage of fracture propagation. When K increases from 0.3 to 0.7, the critical/breakdown pressure is increased by 6.8% from 56.8 MPa to 63.5 MPa. However, as the injection time increases and the fracture propagates, the differences of the injection fluid pressure under different K values become smaller.

Fig. 14
(a) shows the near-well rock fracture trajectories for the different values of pressure transmission coefficient. A smaller K value leads to a sharper inclination of the crack. In other words, a larger pressure transferred onto the rock surface tends to drive the rock fracture along the perforation direction. Fig. 14(b) illustrates the changes of the deflection angle φ under different values of K. The deflection angle has a roughly linear relation to K. When K is increased from 0.3 to 0.7, the turning angle is decreased by 11.2° from 76.1° to 65.8°.
For a given perforation angle, a sharper deflection of the near-well rock fracture makes the fracture propagate to the maximum principal stress direction over a shorter distance, which reduces the breakdown pressure as shown in Fig. 13. Therefore, a larger pressure transmission coefficient will make the near-wellbore fracture closer to the perforation direction but relatively further from the maximum principal stress direction, if they are different. Changing the design of casing and cement sheath will therefore affect the fracking pressure and the fracture tortuosity. If near-wellbore rock fracture tortuosity is desired, Young's modulus of cement can be tuned to reduce the pressure transmitted to the wellbore surface. However, to obtain a smooth fracture for proppant placement and transportation, the thickness of the casing and cement sheath can be reasonably reduced to increase the pressure transmitted on to the wellbore surface. Overall, the well design and selection of casing and cementing material parameters should be considered to best predict the near-wellbore fracture tortuosity.
The angle between the perforation and direction of maximum principal stress is a key parameter for perforation design. Fig. 15
 illustrates the injection pressure development for the perforation angles 0–90°. Due to the symmetricity, it is numerically difficult to simulate the case for the perforation angle 90°; a perforation angle of 89° is used instead. It can be seen that a larger perforation angle incurs a bigger critical/breakdown pressure. For example, the breakdown pressure for the perforation angle 89° (for 90°) is 66.8 MPa which is 37% higher than that for the perforation angle 0°. Moreover, the steady pressure for the fracture propagation is smaller when the perforation angle is smaller. Therefore, to reduce the injection pressure for hydraulic fracturing, the preferred perforation should be ideally along the direction of the maximum principal stress (i.e., θ = 0°). Fig. 16
 shows the fracture trajectories for different perforation angles. It can be seen that, first, the fractures are reoriented towards the direction of the maximum principal stress, as expected; second, the deflection angle of the fracture increases as the perforation angle is increased. However, the change of the deflection angle becomes steady for larger values of the perforation angle. Therefore, if the preferred angle of 0° for the perforation construction cannot be precisely achieved in practice due to unknown in-situ stress condition, the perforation angle should preferably be kept between 0 and 30° to reduce the near-wellbore rock fracture complexity.

It can be found that increase of the stress ratio will increase the critical/breakdown pressure for this perforation angle. This is because a larger stress ratio can lead to increased stress concentration in the rock at the crack path in the model. Moreover, the pressure for fracture propagation is larger for a larger stress ratio. Fig. 18
 shows the fracture trajectories and deflection angles for different stress ratios. It can be seen that, the smaller the stress ratio, the smaller the deflection angle. For the stress ratio of 1, rock is cracked along the perforation direction with the deflection angle equal to 0. The deflection angle reaches over 60° for the stress ratio greater than 1.1. In summary, the near-wellbore rock fracture will deflect towards the direction of the maximum principal stress over a shorter distance in a rock formation with a higher stress ratio.
The ratio of the perforation depth to the well radius (L/R – L is perforation depth and R is the radius of the well) is a basic parameter for perforation design. Fig. 19
 illustrates the pressure development for the different depths of perforation with the perforation angle 60° and the stress ratio 1.5. It can be seen that larger perforation length leads to smaller breakdown pressure. This may be because a longer perforation makes the rock fracture further away from the stress concentration zone induced by the well excavation. It may also be related to the size effect of fracture for quasi-brittle materials
35
 as a longer crack yields more strain energy to release (larger stripe areas from above and below the crack surface). Therefore, it is helpful to design a deeper perforation to reduce the hydraulic fracking pressure. Fig. 20
 shows the fracture trajectories and deflection angles for different ratios of perforation depth to well radius. The fracture trajectories are basically similar and the deflection angle slightly decreases from 70.6° to 67.4° when the ratio of perforation depth to well radius increased from 1 to 3.
To further discuss the effect of perforation depth to fracture trajectories, comparisons of fracture trajectories and deflection angles for different stress ratios are carried out. Fig. 21
(a) and (b) show the fracture trajectories for the stress ratios 1.05 and 1.1, respectively. It can be seen that the perforation depth significantly affects the fracture trajectories. The deeper the perforation is, the closer the fracture propagates to the perforation direction. Fig. 21(c) shows the deflection angles for the stress ratios 1.05, 1.1 and 1.5 showing that the deflection angles are decreased by increasing the perforation depth for a small stress ratio. For the stress ratio 1.1, the deflection angle is reduced from 58.4° to 28.8° when L/R is increased from 1 to 3. Therefore, it can be postulated that, for rock formation with small in-situ stress difference, improving the perforation depth would be beneficial in terms of reducing the near-wellbore fracture tortuosity.


6
Conclusions
In this paper, a combined analytical-numerical method has been developed to simulate the near-wellbore fracture of rock for a cased and cemented well with perforation. An analytical model for calculating the pressure acting on the wellbore surface was firstly derived. Then the pressure was accordingly updated and applied to the wellbore surface based on the analytical model and injection pressure, which was achieved by an in-house FORTRAN subroutine in the ABAQUS solver. A worked example was presented to demonstration the application of the developed model and a deflection angle was defined to describe the tortuosity of near-wellbore fracture. The numerical results are in good agreement with the experimental results. A comprehensive parametric study was carried out to investigate the sensitivities of some key parameters on the injection pressure development and fracture trajectory. It has been found that the ratio of pressure on wellbore surface to the injection pressure (i.e., pressure transmission coefficient K) varies from about 0.2 to 0.7. The pressure transmission coefficient K decreases with the increasing of the thickness of casing and cement sheath, and Young's modulus of casing. However, with the increase of Young's modulus of the cement sheath from 2 to 40 GPa, the pressure transmission coefficient first sharply increases and then flattens roughly around 15 GPa. The larger the pressure transmission coefficient K is, the larger the breakdown pressure is and the fracture propagates more closely to the perforation orientation with a smaller deflection angle. The near-well tortuosity of the crack can be reduced by decreasing the thickness of casing and cement sheath, reducing Young's modulus of casing and increasing Young's modulus of cement up to around 15 GPa, based on the realistic range of values of the well parameters. Moreover, the larger the perforation angle is, the larger the breakdown pressure and deflection angle are. The near-wellbore fracture will deflect towards the direction of maximum principal stress in a short distance in the rock formation with a high stress difference. For a rock formation with a small stress difference, improving the perforation depth is helpful for reducing the near-wellbore fracture tortuosity. The modelling results in this paper show that the design of casing and cement sheath affects the pressure transmission on the wellbore surface, the breakdown pressure and fracture propagation near the wellbore. There is potential to affect the fracture tortuosity through understanding of the in-situ stress ahead of wellbore completion and design of the casing-cement system.

1
Introduction
Steep rock walls are characterized by a marked predisposition to rockfall, which is defined as the detachment and subsequent fall, bouncing, rolling, sliding, and deposition of rock fragments under the influence of gravity.
1
 As opposed to the flow-like behavior of rock avalanches, rockfalls show no significant interaction between individual particles, meaning that their downslope propagation can be simulated by numerical models based on rigid body ballistics.
2
 This type of landslide represents a major hazard across most populated mountain landscapes and surface mining operations, affecting high slopes as well as single bedrock outcrops. It may originate as a result of a wide variety of slope instability mechanisms, involving from single pebbles to catastrophic failure of thousands of cubic meters.
3

,

4


The management of rockfall hazards and associated risks primarily depends on the knowledge of the whereabouts and timing of rockfall triggering. The timing is typically elusive: while accelerating displacements leading to slope collapse and ensuing rockfall have been reported,
5–7
 precursors are undetectable or very short-lived when instabilities are relatively small in volume and/or in hard rocks. Many authors have therefore focused their attention on the concept of rockfall susceptibility, namely the estimation of how likely rockfalls are at a specific site—from the scale of single slopes to entire valleys. In this sense, approaches can be broadly divided into two categories: frequency–magnitude distributions of future rockfall occurrence may be inferred from geological/morphometric parameters
8–12
 and the compilation of rockfall inventories
4

,

13–17
; alternatively, location and type of source mechanisms may be evaluated through explicit consideration of rock mass structure.
18–21
 The latter approach is rooted in the notion that the development of failure mechanisms is largely governed by the intensity of rock mass jointing and the geometric arrangement of discontinuities intersecting the rock face. The tendency to instability may then be expressed in terms of factors of safety derived from deterministic/stress-strain solutions (e.g., limit equilibrium, discrete element), or in terms of the kinematic feasibility of block movement (e.g., kinematic analysis). Deterministic/stress-strain solutions are numerically more rigorous, but have a narrower applicability (usually limited to the analysis of selected rock compartments) and must be constrained by input data from extensive laboratory testing and fieldwork. Methods predicated on the principles of stereographic-based kinematic analysis, which aim to identify where the kinematic conditions for block detachment are theoretically met, can rather be applied expeditiously at the scale of entire slopes.
Advanced surveying instruments such as terrestrial laser scanner (TLS) have now become common tools for the creation of high-resolution three-dimensional models of steep rocky slopes, from which not only the morphology of the terrain, but also orientation and other relevant discontinuity properties can be extracted.
22–24
 This has proved to be invaluable in vast, dangerous, or otherwise inaccessible scenarios, where traditional scanline surveying cannot be carried out. Discontinuity planes may be mapped either on polygonal meshes or directly on raw point cloud data, and typically in much greater number than what is practically achievable with traditional methods. Fitting routines may require manual input from the user
25
 or be semi-automatic. To cite just a few examples from the second group, Vöge et al.
26
 developed a series of algorithms to identify discontinuity planes based on the angular deviation of the nodes of polygonal meshes. Riquelme et al.
27
 proposed a method for grouping discontinuity sets in point cloud data by means of a kernel density estimation and outlining single discontinuities by means of a density-based clustering algorithm. Matasci et al.
21
 presented a successful application of the Coltop3D code, which allows the definition of discontinuity sets by computing dip and dip direction of each point in the cloud with respect to a set of neighbors.
This increased capability of collecting topographic and rock mass structural data now makes it possible to also refine the thoroughness of kinematically-based rock slope stability assessments. The present paper focuses on the enhanced quantification of rockfall hazards in steep rock walls by exploiting high-resolution point cloud data acquired from terrestrial laser scanning. The proposed analysis workflow is the outcome from a decennial research effort on the topic and multiple field experiences.
28–35
 Building upon the semi-automatic extraction of key discontinuity properties by means of the established DiAna
29
 (Discontinuity Analysis) approach, an upgraded Matlab routine (named DiAna-K) is introduced to calculate the probability of structurally controlled instabilities based on an extended three-dimensional derivation of kinematic analysis principles. Indexes of rockfall susceptibility are conceived to explicitly account for the presence of overhanging surfaces—where failure of rock in tension may produce free fall mechanisms—and specific friction coefficients for discontinuity sets, planes, or lines of intersection between planes. The term “overhanging” is herein adopted to indicate a jutting portion of the rock wall that, contrarily to “normal” rock wall areas, is oriented in the direction of lower elevation. The main features of the method are highlighted by surveying a steep rock wall at an abandoned quarry near the town of Florence (Central Italy) historically affected by rockfall hazards.


2
Materials and methods

2.1
Test site and TLS survey
The method described in the next paragraphs was applied at the rock wall of an abandoned quarry 5 km N of the town of Florence (Central Italy). The SSW–NNE trending sub-vertical quarry face, with a height of ∼25 m and a width of ∼70 m, was excavated into Oligocene–Miocene foredeep turbidites belonging to the Macigno Formation, consisting of an alternation of medium to thick beds (up to 10 m) of coarse-grained sandstones and thin, more sporadic beds of finer grained pelitic deposits. Instability mechanisms of different type and size arise from the changing mechanical strength and tendency to weathering across the various bedding strata, which are systematically intersected by high-angle discontinuities. A RIEGL VZ1000 terrestrial laser scanner was employed to collect high-resolution point clouds of the quarry face with a mean spacing of 8 mm. Occlusions were reduced by performing acquisitions from two different points of view, with a distance from the rock wall of 25–30 m. Six marker reflectors were distributed across the quarry floor, and their coordinates were surveyed with a geodetic Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver. This operation allowed the correct alignment and georeferencing of the point clouds. During the scan, an integrated Nikon D700 camera captured a series of partially overlapping panoramic photographs that were subsequently stitched together in order to drape the three-dimensional model of the rock wall with its true colors. The final merged point cloud, generated through use of the RiSCAN PRO software package, is composed of more than 100 million points (Fig. 1
). The related polygonal mesh covers an area of 1043.42 m2, with a mean mesh element size of 2.06 × 10−3 m2.


2.2
Brief overview of DiAna and derivation of full three-dimensional kinematic analysis (Diana-K)
Modes of failure across rocky slopes can be examined using the principles of stereographic-based kinematic analysis. Developed by several authors,
28

,

36–41
 kinematic analysis of block stability is aimed at identifying the areas of the rock face where the geometric arrangement of discontinuities renders a structurally controlled failure kinematically feasible. The approach is highly instrumental in predicting the most probable rockfall source areas and designing appropriate containment measures. Discontinuities are assumed to be infinitely persistent, and the contribution to the joint shear strength to be exclusively due to friction. The quality of outputs is naturally influenced by how well the sampled discontinuities reproduce the actual rock mass configuration. Here, an established semi-automatic approach named DiAna (Discontinuity Analysis)
29
 was used to map discontinuities at the test site and extract six of the associated key parameters suggested by ISRM
42
 for their quantitative description—namely orientation, JRC, number of sets, spacing/frequency, persistence, and block size. Of these, the first two can be directly inputted in subsequent kinematic analysis. Nonetheless, the kinematic tests built into the upgraded Diana-K routine may also be run by inputting discontinuity properties collected through traditional geomechanical surveying or other semi-automatic methods. Likewise, other techniques (e.g., photogrammetric surveying) may be used to input topographic data into DiAna and DiAna-K; but, in the authors’ experience, TLS surveys are best able to model sharp edges and rough surfaces, which so fundamentally characterize jointed sub-vertical rock walls.
In short, the rationale of the original DiAna routine

A least-squares fitting plane is then assigned to each sub-group of points. 3
Results
The aforementioned kinematic tests help define the rock wall areas that are more prone to structurally controlled instability, namely the areas where rockfall hazard is greater. The susceptibility to rockfalls due to a certain failure mechanism can be visually assessed by draping the polygonal mesh according to a color ramp. The color of each mesh element is determined by the locally computed value, on a range from 0% to 100%, of the susceptibility index in question (as derived from Eqs. ((8), (16), (25), (31) and (36)). In general, there is no objective way to determine what constitutes a high or low rockfall susceptibility, as this depends on the spatial distribution of the computed values as well as the total number of sampled discontinuities and intersections. The procedure is not to be seen as a replacement for field observations and geomechanical analysis of single rock compartments, which are essential for examining the continuity of highly susceptible areas, the presence of weak structures, and the size of potential instabilities. Moreover, the role played by external factors in promoting rockfalls (e.g., rainfall, freeze-thaw, seismic activity, wind-induced leverage by tree roots) is necessarily neglected.

Fig. 7 shows the contour plot of the poles to discontinuities (equal angle, lower hemisphere projection) extracted from application of the DiAna routine at the quarry test site. It should be noted that the classification into discontinuity sets is for illustrative purposes and does not have any influence on Diana-K. The results of the rockfall susceptibility assessment are then shown in Figs. 8–11



. A dynamic perspective of the quarry slope, intermittently overlain by the computed maps of susceptibility to the different failure mechanisms, is also provided in Supplementary Videos S1–S4. It is interesting to note that wedge (Fig. 9 and Supplementary Video S2) and flexural toppling failure (Fig. 10 and Supplementary Video S3) appear to be more likely from a spatial perspective, as related indexes of susceptibility (S

ftf

This confirms that wedge failure, and secondarily flexural toppling, are statistically prevalent (comparatively higher S

Validation of a procedure for rockfall susceptibility assessment may be carried out in two ways: by direct observation of several rockfall events and comparison of their source location with the predicted areas of greater hazard; or by visual inspection of the rock wall to confirm whether the predicted structures are actually identifiable at the surface. The first approach may be very time consuming, as many years may need to pass before a sufficient number of detectable rockfalls occur. Since the investigated rock wall is of limited size and easily accessible, ground-truthing was deemed as an efficient mean for results validation. With the exception of the unlikely block toppling mechanism, some illustrative photographs are provided as insets to Fig. 12. These demonstrate that areas of higher computed susceptibility are consistent with the presence of block geometries that are evidently prone to the predicted mode of failure. It is also worth mentioning that high values of susceptibility to free fall and wedge failure are located in proximity of an overhanging area of the rock wall that was affected by a rockfall of approximately 100 m3 few years prior to the survey (panel ‘a’ in Fig. 12).


4
Discussion
Thorough quantification of rockfall hazards is strictly dependent on realistic sampling of discontinuity and rock face orientations. In this sense, the proposed Diana-K approach is founded on the ability of TLS to produce three-dimensional representations of the observed scenario by measuring with millimetric to centimetric accuracy the distance of a regular pattern of millions of points in a polar coordinate system. With the ever increasing availability of computing power, the extraction of discontinuity orientations directly from raw point cloud data (as done in DiAna) is a definite advantage with respect to mesh-based applications, whose quality can be influenced by the distortion of polygonal surfaces in the triangulation process.
24
 In Diana-K, rockfall susceptibility is subsequently assessed in similar semi-automatic manner on the basis of stereographic-based kinematic analysis, hence it is treated as a geometric problem solely driven by rock mass structure and rock face orientation. Complex geometries involving multiple basal, rear, and lateral release surfaces are not taken into consideration. The analysis also excludes processes of intact rock fracture and external forces such as water pressures or reinforcement, which can significantly influence stability. Design procedures should entail preliminary kinematic analysis to identify where the conditions for block sliding or rotation are more pronounced, and then focused deterministic/stress-strain analysis to infer local factors of safety.
41


Predictions of kinematic instability have mostly been carried out in previous studies by combining the orientation of mesh elements (or point cloud data) with the mean orientation of discontinuity sets.
21

,

46
 This is a major simplification with respect to the natural scatter of discontinuity orientations in rock masses. To better deal with the issue, some authors
47

,

48
 proposed to treat discontinuity orientation as a random variable, as for example in a Monte Carlo framework. These works proved that, in rough rock faces with markedly non-uniform orientation, little variations in input structural data may lead to kinematic evaluations significantly biased towards unsafety. Diana-K overcomes the uncertainties inherent to modeling the distribution of discontinuity orientations, since these are comprehensively sampled from TLS data. Probabilistic context is rather provided by coupling iteratively each mesh element with the orientation of each mapped discontinuity/intersection (or possible combination thereof). It is therefore assumed that any mapped discontinuity/intersection may intersect a given point of the rock face. Local susceptibility to a certain mode of failure is consequently expressed by the relative amount of features theoretically able to satisfy the associated kinematic requirements.
The Diana-K routine also allows incorporation of additional spatial arguments by assigning distinct weighting factors (D

This is aimed at yielding results that better reflect local rock mass conditions, and is achieved by measuring the distance (D) between the center of gravity of the discontinuity planes and the center of gravity of the mesh element under analysis. While the kinematic feasibility of wedge and flexural toppling failure is comparatively dominant over most portions of the surveyed face, in absolute terms the highest hazard is attributed to plane and free fall mechanisms potentially originating from highly steep areas of limited extent. This kind of distinction, related to the presence of small-scale overhangs, may not be obtained from traditional methods of rockfall hazard assessment that employ airborne-based digital elevation models.

With reference to active surface mining operations and artificial slopes in general, another implication of the proposed procedure is that it offers a framework to search for the geometric configuration of the excavation that best minimizes rockfall hazards. A sensitivity analysis can be performed to understand how indexes of rockfall susceptibility are influenced by the dip and dip direction of the cut face. For example, variations of GKI may be examined by hypothesizing different dip increments for a fixed dip direction of the cut face; or alternatively, by hypothesizing different dip direction increments for a fixed dip of the cut face.
28
 This is particularly relevant in open-pit mines: as cut faces take the full range of possible dip directions, their dip may be adjusted from one pit sector to the other in order to meet a targeted level of safety. Knowledge of feasible instability mechanisms is also informative for interpreting the geometry of slope movement vectors, which in turn can significantly affect the measurement accuracy of line-of-sight slope monitoring techniques such as ground-based interferometric radar.
51
 Displacement/velocity data may be corrected by estimating the sensitivity of the sensor against the estimated direction of slope movement, thus providing valuable context for the appropriate assessment of ongoing instabilities and the calibration of related alarms.


5
Conclusions
The presented analysis workflow is concerned with the thorough quantification of rockfall hazards from remotely sensed surface data. It exploits semi-automatic routines for the extraction of discontinuity planes (DiAna) as well as the assessment of structurally controlled rockfall susceptibility scenarios (DiAna-K). The procedure is not to be viewed as a univocal replacement for traditional geomechanical surveying, but rather as an approach that becomes an inevitable necessity to practitioners who must collect data in vast, dangerous, or otherwise inaccessible environments. Potential modes of failure identified at the quarry test site agree well with evidences gathered in the field, with the added benefit given by the ability to rapidly investigate areas of large extent and marked steepness—including truly overhanging rock faces. Further steps, among which the possibility to assign spatial weighting and distinct friction angles, can be taken to better incorporate the characteristics of single discontinuities/intersections into the analysis of complex scenarios. Further verification of the method could be conducted by integrating the kinematic analysis outputs with spatially continuous slope deformation data or detailed rockfall inventories at sites of frequent rockfall occurrence, with the goal of deriving explicit correlations between statistically likely (i.e., predicted) and actually ongoing instabilities. The code implemented into the Diana and Diana-K routines may be promptly run on a MATLAB environment even by users who do not possess advanced programming skills.

1
Introduction
The method of hydraulic fracturing (HF) is widely used in reservoir engineering development and in in-situ stress measurement. It is applied to conventional oil and gas extraction, shale gas, and enhanced geothermal systems (EGS) and has become a major research and engineering topic in a large variety of geological conditions. Previous studies have revealed that hydraulic fracturing behavior in crystalline rock (e.g., granite) for geothermal purposes is highly dependent on the present minerals as well as on their grain size and heterogeneity.
1–3
 The fracture growth behaviour in crystalline rock is quite different from that is observed in sedimentary rock (e.g., sandstone), which is considered in oil and gas fracturing.
4–6


The grain-scale heterogeneity of rock has been found to greatly affect crack growth behavior in mechanical fracturing tests. However, rock microstructure has been insufficiently considered in hydraulic fracturing tests (i.e., fluid-driven fracturing). Recent grain-based numerical modeling work reported unique behavior in terms of asymmetric fracture growth, zipper-mode crack initiation, and the partial re-closure of previous cracks in crystalline rock.
7–9
 Cracks can be induced in mineral grains (intragranular or transgranular cracking) or along grain interfaces (grain-boundary cracks).
8

,

10
 An in-depth analysis of the hydraulic fracture path (including acoustic emission monitoring) can shed some light on the fluid-driven fracture nucleation and fracture propagation process.
11

,

12
 While crack nucleation models are available for the mechanical loading of crystalline (wing cracks)
13
 and sedimentary rock (pore cracks),
14
 fluid-driven fracture nucleus and growth path models remain sparse. For example, Lu et al. (2018, 2019) presented a time-dependent hydraulic fracture initiation model that incorporates a subcritical crack growth index and applied this model to data from laboratory experiments on granite, sandstone, and limestone.
15

,

16
 Both the stress intensity factor at the fracture tip and the fracture toughness (critical stress intensity factor of Mode I cracks) play a key role in the damage mechanics of rock fatigue.
17
 Furthermore, a fracture mechanics framework for hydraulic fatigue in rock was proposed and applied to data from granitic rock experiments at three different scales (laboratory, mine and field).
18


At laboratory scale, one focus of hydraulic fracturing experimental study is to compare different injection styles, such as continuous and cyclic injection. Hydraulic fracturing test results in both dry and saturated Tennessee sandstone (6% porosity) have shown that fracturing via cyclic injection had increased the fracture permeability by a factor of three to ten compared with conventional HF.
5
 This finding was confirmed in a recent study on tight sandstone.
19
 For Tennessee sandstone, breakdown pressure (BP) reduction via cyclic injection was only found in dry samples, but not for the saturated samples. It is therefore reasonable to argue that the decrease in BP in dry samples can be largely attributed to the reduction in tensile strength because fluid injection over several cycles had saturated the sample to a certain extent. A laboratory study reported that cyclic injection that employs stepwise pressurization can reduce the monotonic BP of tight and porous sandstones of 1.05% and 13.24% porosity by 7% and 19%, respectively.
20
 In addition, a recent study reported that cyclic hydraulic fracturing (CHF) can reduce fracture surface roughness in glutenite rock.
21
 Both pre-breakdown cyclic injection that aims at BP reduction and the post-breakdown cyclic injection that aims to enhance permeability have been discussed in previous studies.
5

,

22
 Laboratory investigations in Pocheon granite have demonstrated that – compared with HF, CHF can reduce BP by up to 20%, mitigate the maximum amplitude of seismic events occurs during the fracturing, and creates more complex fractures.
23
 In addition, our previous study on the same granite, which was tested under true triaxial stress conditions, found that intragranular cracking dominates for all the specimens while the injection scheme greatly influences the fracture path.
10
 Mine-scale experiments in granite have revealed that CHF can reduce the BP of granite by 10–20%; however, permeability enhancement via CHF is less pronounced compared with that via conventional HF.
24

,

25
 Moreover, numerical modeling has revealed that CHF has the potential to reduce the occurrence of larger-magnitude seismic events in field stimulation.
26
 At field scale, cyclic water injection has typically been used in field tests to improve the oil recovery rate in sandstone formations.
27
 Progressive cyclic injection was reported in hydraulic stimulation of the GPK1 well at the Soultz EGS site and was shown to have lowered the injection pressure for fracture propagation in granite formations.
28


The above-reviewed study revealed that the behavior of HF varies for different rock types and different injection conditions. Mechanism of cyclic injection varies in different rocks and even in the same granitic rocks, because of their different mechanical structures. Hydraulic fatigue does not necessarily occur in every case. To gain a more-in-depth understanding of the underlying physical mechanism of hydraulic fatigue in different types of rock, we selected one fine-grained sandstone and two coarse-grained granites with different fractions of minerals (e.g., quartz, biotite) and different initial defect distributions (i.e., microcracks) in order to investigate their effect on high-cycle hydraulic fatigue experiments with a particular focus on the fluid-driven fracture path at the scale of heterogeneous mineral assembly.


2
Materials and methods
Two types of coarse-grained granite and one fine-grained sandstone were used for hydraulic fracturing experiments in the laboratory. Fig. 1
 presents typical optical microscopic images of the three types of rock before the fracturing experiments had taken place. Pocheon granite (PG) was obtained from the Pocheon area in South Korea. This granite has been frequently used in studies on mechanical and hydraulic fracturing behavior and is composed of 35.7% quartz (Qz), 35.9% orthoclase (Or) mixed with plagioclase (Pl), 25.8% microcline (Mc), and 2.6% biotite (Bt). PG is coarse-grained with an average grain size of around 2.0 mm and 3.2 mm measured in the short- and the long-axis, respectively. It has moderate anisotropy due to abundant microcracks – that is, the Brazilian tensile strength ranges from 7.72 to 10.22 MPa for the three cleavages of rift, grain, and hardway. For detailed physical and mechanical properties (including the anisotropy effect), we refer to Zhuang et al. (2020).
30
 Gonghe granite (GG) was taken from the outcrop in the Gonghe area of China, where EGS projects are currently under development.
31
 GG is composed of 50.2% plagioclase, 21.4% quartz, 13.4% biotite, and 9.4% orthoclase as well as other minor minerals, such as hornblende.
32
 The fraction of biotite is higher compared with that in Pocheon granite, and biotite in GG is either platy or nondescript in terms of grain shape. The average grain size of GG is ∼ 0.9 mm and 1.5 mm measured in the short- and the long-axis, respectively, which is approximately half the average grain size in PG. The gray sandstone (GS) is composed of 53.6% quartz, 22.4% albite, 10.5% calcite, 8.1% muscovite, 2.9% biotite, and 2.7% chlorite. The sample has a porosity of 8.98% and a mean particle size of ∼ 0.1 mm, and was evaluated as being relatively uniform with no significant bedding. Table 1
 summarizes and compares the main physical and mechanical properties of the three types of rock. In particular, the Brazilian tensile strength (BTS) – which directly influences BP for the tensile-dominated hydraulic fracturing process – was reduced by full saturation at about 2.6%, 10.5%, and 42.9% for PG, GG, and GS, respectively. The saturated samples were stored in a water-filled vacuum chamber for more than 12 h.
29
 All the right-circular cylindrical specimens had a diameter of 50 mm and height of 100 mm with a concentric through-going borehole of 5 mm in diameter (d) (Fig. 2
). In addition to the grain size effect, borehole size effect also exists in laboratory hydraulic fracturing tests. Our previous study in the same PG has shown that the monotonic breakdown pressure decreases with increasing borehole size of 5–14 mm.
3
 The borehole diameter determined in this study is larger than the mean grain size in the two granites.
Hydraulic fracturing experiments were conducted on the triaxial testing system that had been introduced in a previous study.

 Tap water was injected from the bottom of the specimen with a clamping vertical pressure of 10 MPa in order to prevent leakage between the borehole and the loading plate. Confining pressure was set to zero in order to allow hydraulic fracturing experiments to be conducted without a triaxial cell, and acoustic emission sensors could therefore be directly installed on the sample surface. As shown in Fig. 2d, six Nano-30 sensors provided by the MISTRAS company were glued to the specimen surface via wax couplant, and plastic bands were used to avoid loose contact between the sensors and rock specimen during the long-duration high-cycle fatigue injection test. In this study, the maximum duration time of tests performed was ∼ 75 h, and the maximum number of cycles was 6200. Volume-rate-controlled continuous (one cycle) and cyclic injection (multiple cycles) were applied (Fig. 3
). Continuous injection employed a constant injection rate of 50 mm3/s until hydraulic breakdown, while in cyclic injection, 50 mm3/s and zero injection rates alternated for one cycle. The durations of high-rate and low-rate injection were determined by the upper and lower limits of the injection pressure, respectively. The duration highly relies on the hydraulic performance of the specimen and could therefore vary after any new crack had been created in the specimen. As the radial dissipation of fluid pressure in the borehole takes a long time for low-permeability rock, the interval for the zero injection was fixed to 120 s for PG, to 480 s for GG, and to 60 s for GS, thereby allowing the injection pressure drop to a relatively low value (i.e., <20%) compared with the upper limit of the injection pressure during the high-rate injection. Previous studies have pointed out that the injection duration and the interval may influence the total number of cycles required to breakdown the specimen.
