Analysis of hydraulic fracture path at grain scale
Compared with sandstone composed of a majority of sand-sized silicate grain, most granite is typically multi-mineral rock with common types of minerals, such as quartz, alkali feldspar, plagioclase, and biotite. Grain size and mineral composition in granite have been reported to have a significant influence on hydraulic fracturing behavior.
2

,

11
 To further understand both how hydraulic fracture are formed and the impact of different minerals, we conducted CT observations and microscopic examinations (thin-section analysis) on the hydraulic fracture path in the fractured specimens. The thin sections were decided at cross-sections showing the relatively large-aperture fractures based on CT scanning results of the fractured specimens. Typically, they appeared at the top half of the specimen, 10 mm away from the top surface.

4.1
Hydraulic fracture geometry

Fig. 7
 displays a typical CT image of the cross-section of the cylindrical specimens in CHF tests in the three types of rock. Fig. 8
 presents typical microscopic images of selected thin-sections in CHF tests from the three types of rock. For more CT images and microscopic images of both HF and CHF tests, we refer to the Supplementary Information (Figs. S1–S6). The yellow color indicates the hydraulic fracture path. Defects in fractured samples are infilled with epoxy resin with yellow dyes via suction in order to enhance the observation of the fractures. As can be confirmed from Figs. 7 and 8 and the Supplementary Information, bi-wing fractures are frequently generated along both sides of a borehole but are not always oriented in the same direction. In most cases, a fracture on one side of the borehole is larger than that on the other side (asymmetric bi-wings). The large fracture half-length and tortuosity are measured for all the test cases, and their average values are listed in Table 2. Fracture tortuosity was 1.03–1.07 in the two granites, which was slightly higher than the 1.02 measured in the sandstone. There was little difference for the large fracture half-length between HF and CHF for PG and GS, though the reason for this was different for the two different rocks. Unlike in the sandstone, in which most hydraulic fractures in both HF and CHF were relatively straight (Fig. 7c), hydraulic fractures created by CHF in some individual cases of PG were tortuous; however, they were not able to propagate to the outside boundary and thus lowered the average fracture length (Fig. S1b). Our previous study on a 100-mm cubic specimen of the same PG under true triaxial stress conditions reported a tortuosity of around 1.03–1.1 depending on different injection schemes, including cyclic injection.
10
 In the present study, the ratio of intragranular and intergranular (grain-boundary) fractures in PG is approximately 4:1, as shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b), which is quantitatively consistent with our previous findings in hydraulic fracturing of the same PG.
10
 One previous study found that the bonding strength between grain boundaries was usually lower than the tensile strength of the individual minerals – that is, quartz and feldspar.
36
 The fraction of grain-boundary fractures in GG is ∼ 35% in the case of Figs. 8c and 49% in Fig. 8d, both of which are higher than the corresponding fraction observed in PG. The difference between the two granites is closely related to mineral compositions. For example, PG is composed of a large number of quartz grains that are more fractured while GG has a larger proportion of biotite. We further analyze the role of quartz and biotite grains during fracture propagation below.

Fig. 8(e) and (f) display microscope images and backscattered electron composition (BEC) images, respectively, for two fractured sandstone specimens in CHF. Breakage of both sand grains and cements occurred along the fracture path. Fracture branching was not observed at the borehole scale (>1 mm), though it was confirmed at the grain scale (0.1 mm). The phenomenon of branching is recognized as damage zones. In addition, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis on the fractures indicates the presence of illite and carbonate.
37




4.2
Secondary fracture
Secondary fractures were less common in the sandstone compared with those in the two granites. In addition, we observed hydraulic fracture branching that was more obvious in CHF compared with in HF in the two granites (e.g., Fig. 8a–d), which is consistent with our previous findings.
23
 Compared with the continuous injection in HF, cyclic injection with long duration created a larger infiltration zone with an increasing number of cycles. As a result, tensile cracks or hydro-shears could be generated farther away from the borehole in addition to the hydraulic fracture initiated at the early stage.
3

Fig. 8a shows an example in PG in which multiple fractures were initiated at the borehole wall, but only one fracture continued to propagate as the main hydraulic fracture with relatively larger aperture and fracture length.

Fig. 8c displays a typical case that occurred in high-cycle hydraulic fracturing of GG with 1600 cycles of injection. Bi-wing fractures were formed at the beginning, whereas the main hydraulic fracture deviated from the initial propagation direction on one side and a secondary fracture was observed at the fracture intersection point that was aligned with the new propagation direction. For a detailed observation of the relative locations, 3D CT reconstruction of the two fractures and mineral grains adjacent to the fractures was conducted, as shown in Fig. 9
. Compared with the CT image before fracturing, we confirmed that the secondary fracture had occurred along a pre-existing natural crack. The hydraulic fracture met the crack with an approach angle of around 40° and then activated the pre-existing flaw together with crack dilation (aperture increase). We attribute this type of interaction between hydraulic fracture and a pre-existing crack to the high-cycle fatigue process. Hydraulic energy is spent in order to promote fractures in a larger portion of weak volumes of rock that are affected by the fatigue process, and to enhance further fluid infiltration. Depressurization (relaxation) phases in the cyclic injection allow the fracture path to be reoriented in terms of lower energy (pre-existing flaw direction), which is prevented in conventional hydraulic fracturing since the pressure is increased monotonically (no relaxation phases). In another case, a pre-existing crack in GG was located almost perpendicular to the direction of hydraulic fracture propagation, and HF was arrested by the natural obstacle, as shown in Fig. S6(c).


4.3
The role of quartz grains in the hydraulic fracturing of granite
In comparison with GG, PG has a three-times-larger fraction of quartz grains, and pre-existing microcracks are abundant in quartz grains, as shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b). These microcracks enable PG to have a permeability of around two orders of magnitude higher than that of almost impermeable granite. It can therefore be expected that for the same duration, the fluid infiltration volume via cyclic injection in PG should be larger. In addition, fractured quartz grains have lower tensile strength compared with that of other grains, and fluid pressure is more-easily built surrounding fractured quartz clusters because they are relatively more permeable due to microcracks. As a result, we observed more quartz grains distributed along hydraulic fractures in PG that consisted of both intragranular fractures in quartz grains and intergranular fractures between quartz and other minerals. For the PG specimen fractured by 109 cycles in Fig. 8(a) and (b), the total fraction of hydraulic fractures involved with quartz grains was ∼ 47%. This can also be one reason why quartz fragments can serve as natural proppants more frequently during the fatigue hydraulic fracturing process, in particular under the conditions of cyclic injection combined with pulse pressure, which has been reported in previous study.
10

,

18




4.4
The role of biotite plates in the hydraulic fracturing of granite
Biotite (platy minerals) often presents in a shape with a relatively higher aspect ratio than other major minerals, such as quartz and feldspar, as has been confirmed via CT and microscope images. Mineral orientation influences fracture propagation and sometimes enables the hydraulic fracture to be more tortuous. For example, previous study has identified mica plates in granitic rock as one reason for increased hydraulic fracture tortuosity.
3
 Intragranular fracture in biotite usually propagates along its short axis, particularly in GG (Fig. 8c and d). Intergranular fractures along the grain boundary of biotite are frequently observed. In general, more biotite grains interact with the hydraulic fracture in GG compared with in PG, largely because biotite content is 2.6 times higher in GG.
For the same rock, fractures created by CHF show slightly higher tortuosity than those created by HF in GG, while the difference is negligible for PG and GS. One observation from CT images provided the reason that hydraulic fracture can suddenly change its orientation during its propagation when meeting specific mineral grains, such as the platy or elongate-shaped biotite (Fig. 7a and b), and the maximum change in orientation was estimated to be larger than 20°. It should be noted that differential horizontal stress was not able to be considered in this study. As a result, fracture propagation was simply controlled by the intrinsic rock microstructure. We expected a stress deviator to support the fracture path tortuosity because favorably oriented platy minerals or foliation should reactivate due to stress differences that also exist farther away from the hydraulic fracture path. When the maximum principal stress is parallel to the preferred mineral orientation or foliation, the hydraulic fracture propagates along the foliation and is relatively straight; otherwise hydraulic fracture propagation deviates from the direction of maximum principal stress when meeting weak local structures, and fracture path thus becomes longer and more tortuous.
3





5
High-cycle hydraulic fatigue behaviour at long-duration injection
In this section, we try to separate the effect of number of injection cycles and the duration of injection cycles on failure behavior of rock although in the experiments one cannot rule out their combined impact on sample failure during the fatigue process. While the logarithmic number of injection cycles is important for the linear decrease in breakdown pressure of rock, the tensile-strength degradation due to tap water rock interaction is important to understand long-duration injection behavior of rock.

5.1
Tensile-strength degradation induced by long-duration cyclic injection
One previous study in addition to the present investigation has shown that the effects of cyclic injection on both BP and crack formation are highly rock-type dependent.
1
 In general, a BP reduction in CHF can be attributed both to hydraulic fatigue at the mineral scale and to strength degradation at the macro-scale (the core scale in the present study), and these two aspects are closely correlated. Here, we consider the hydraulic fracturing process to simply be separated into the two phases of initiation and propagation (crack interaction and coalescence are not considered because the focus is on single bi-wing hydraulic fractures). In fracture mechanics, fracture toughness plays the key role in the initiation phase, while in the propagation phase, mineral- and bonding-strength at micro-scale and the intact rock strength (tensile strength in case of tensile failure) at macro-scale plays the key role in determining how the fracture morphology develops in terms of fracture aperture, length, tortuosity.
7–9

,

38
 Tensile strength degradation via water saturation is significant in high-porosity sandstones, and could reach beyond 40–50% of tensile strength at full saturation. As a result, BP reduction in CHF could be more significant in sandstone during the initially dry state compared with during the saturated state. For example, Patel et al. (2017) reported that cyclic injection can reduce BP in dry Tennessee sandstone (6% porosity), but not for the fully saturated specimen.
5
 The degree of saturation increases with an increasing number of injection cycles in initially dry porous sandstone specimens. Unlike in porous sandstone, tensile strength degradation with water saturation in most granites is less important. For example, PG shows only a limited decrease of 2.6%. For low-permeability granite containing few microcracks and mainly closed pores, such as GG in this study, it is impossible to fully saturate the granite specimen even under the long duration of cyclic injection. In addition, our previous study has uncovered that there is no significant difference in the monotonic breakdown pressure for dry and saturated PG specimens.
29




5.2
High-cycle fatigue
Hydraulic fatigue is a combined effect of cyclic loading in fracture and fluid infiltration that involves both the impact of subcritical crack growth under given fluid injection conditions and the impact of fracture propagation (fracture path complexity and tortuosity). Fatigue hydraulic fracturing (FHF) is a general, umbrella term used to group hydraulic fatigue processes in rock mass using pressure cycles (cyclic hydraulic fracturing) and/or pressure oscillations such as hydraulic pulse (pulse hydraulic fracturing).
3

,

24
 Cyclic and pulse hydraulic fracturing are sub-groups of fatigue hydraulic fracturing. In addition, the term pneumatic hydraulic fracturing has recently been introduced when replacing the fracturing fluid by a pressurized gas medium,
39
 which can be seen as another subgroup of FHF. Cyclic loading under either quasi-static or dynamic condition was reported to cause accumulative damage inside the sample before the ultimate failure, as determined from micro-scale investigations on the failure pattern.
40–43
 Hydraulic fatigue is different from mechanical fatigue. The impact of fluid infiltration cannot be ignored, even for granite with relatively low permeability.
10

,

23

,

29
 In fact, we directly observed that injection water flowed out of the specimen during cyclic injection in all the three types of rock, as we had removed the triaxial cell and confining stress had not been employed in the present study. Infiltration volume increases with increasing cycles of injection as defects (pores and microcracks) and grain boundaries (i.e., quartz) provide a fluid pathway.
44
 However, for relatively low-permeability granite, many cycles are required to build a certain fluid infiltration volume. According to the Haimson and Fairhurst breakdown model, injection fluid leak-off and consequent the poroelastic effect in granite matrix enable the monotonic breakdown pressure to be reduced, compared with theoretical model on impermeable rocks.
45

,

46
 Our previous study has pointed out the much higher monotonic breakdown pressure in PG if fluid infiltration was excluded.
47
 On top of the fluid infiltration effect, in this study, we further discuss on the high-cycle fatigue possibly has further reduced the monotonic breakdown pressure, due to a different fracture propagation pattern.
The number of loading cycles (N) required to breakdown the rock specimen varies from case to case. Previous studies have reported that in general, N increases with decreasing maximum injection pressure.
23

,

32
 However, this finding is affected by other factors, such as the durations of the injection at low and high pressure as well as the rock type. Nevertheless, hard evidence on the influence of the durations in cyclic injection have not yet been reported despite a preliminary investigation.
33
 A few studies have discussed delayed hydraulic fracture initiation, in which the time of breakdown (in logarithmic scale) decreases with increasing wellbore pressure.
16

,

48

,

49
 The subcritical crack growth index was employed to predict the fracture-tip velocity or the fracture growth rate assuming that the fracture can be initiated when the Mode-Ⅰ stress intensity is lower than the critical fracture toughness.
16
 A recent study employed semi-circular bend tests on sandstone composed of 5% cement of argillaceous materials and investigated the effects of water- and acid erosions and found that fluid erosions in sandstone significantly influence the subcritical crack-growth process due to chemical reactions that were pertinent to the cementing agent and the grain boundaries of the sandstone.
50
 Weak grain contacts and boundaries promote crack growth, which results in a decrease in fracture toughness and therefore in faster crack propagation. Unlike in fluid erosions in sandstone, our previous study on PG found that the influence of water saturation is insignificant and that the fracture toughness of PG is approximately proportional to BTS in both dry and fully saturated states.
29


In addition, we compared the four cases in GG fractured by 6, 100, 1,600, and 6200 cycles (Fig. 8c and d and Fig. S6) and found that the high-cycle cases showed a relatively larger proportion of intergranular fractures (about 35% and 49%) compared with those in the two low-cycle cases (about 20% and 26%). We thus deduced that high-cycle fatigue had likely contributed to fracture propagation along grain boundaries.



6
Discussion
The mechanism of CHF clearly differs in granite and sandstone, as is evident in the above comparison of hydraulic fracturing behavior and hydraulic fracture patterns. A few factors affect hydraulic fracture growth during cyclic injection, such as mineral content, grain size and grain interlocking, matrix permeability, dynamic fracture extension, and the design of fatigue cycles. To further interpret these influencing factors, we present schematic diagrams that explain hydraulic fracturing in coarse-grained granite versus fine-grained sandstone, as shown in Fig. 10
.
Grain size as well as grain shape significantly influence the hydraulic fracturing mechanism. In this study, the average grain size (d
50) was comparable to the borehole diameter (d = 5 mm) only in the two coarse-grained granites. Large grains have a size similar to the borehole diameter and are frequently observed in quartz and orthoclase compared with other minerals. Ishida et al. (2000) investigated hydraulic fracturing in four granitic rocks with different mean grain sizes (0.51–1.12 mm) under true triaxial stress conditions and pointed out that the dominant fracturing mechanism at grain scale shifted from tensile to shear with increasing grain size (d/d
50 decreases from 20 to 9).
2
 In the present study, the confining pressure was zero, and horizontal differential stress was not considered. As a result, hydraulic fracturing was tensile dominated in all the three rocks, and BP was therefore close to the tensile strength of the rock. For the highly permeable fine-grained GS (d/d
50 ≈ 50) with sub-rounded grain shape, because the microstructure was quite uniform and the bedding was not significant. In most cases, a bi-wing fracture was formed (Fig. 8e) while the fracture half-length was asymmetric on both sides (Fig. S3).
For an initially dry or partially saturated reservoir rock, fluid infiltration cannot be ignored – even in relatively low-permeable granite – because fluid leak-off in the rock matrix influences the fluid pressure built. Cyclic injection with more cycles creates a larger infiltration area, and fluid pressure in the rock matrix at a certain radial distance (r) away from the borehole can be estimated by P(r), as shown in Fig. 10a. The BP is smaller when considering the poroelastic effect compared with the prediction given by the hydraulic fracturing breakdown model assuming that the rock was impermeable.
45

,

46
 In addition, the larger infiltration is beneficial for complex fracture patterns because the pre-existing defects (microcracks and natural fractures) can be activated, and tortuous fractures can be formed because the hydraulic energy is more likely to be consumed in order to break weak parts in the specimen, such as grain boundaries or fractured mineral grains. We mentioned that 20%–50% of intergranular fractures had been observed in the two granites, and we additionally found that most of these intergranular fractures were farther away from the borehole (at least one borehole diameter). As we explained in a previous study, the large grain size (comparable to the borehole size) does not allow for a Mode-Ⅰ fracture process zone to be developed further.
3
 As illustrated in Fig. 10a, for coarse-grained granite, tensile-dominated hydraulic fractures are formed with both intragranular and intergranular fractures. In addition, the microstructural heterogeneity in granite – particularly the presence of platy biotite grains and their orientation – enables the fracture path to be more tortuous and hydraulic fractures to deviate from the direction of maximum principal stress. This effect on hydraulic fracture tortuosity by biotite minerals is expected to be more pronounced if stress deviators come into play, such as under triaxial or true-triaxial testing. We suggest further investigating the impact of hydraulic fatigue under various confining stresses.
In comparison with hydraulic fractures in coarse-grained granite, tensile cracks that break cementing among sand grains are mainly formed in fine-grained sandstone, as shown by the fracture process zone and the damage zone in Fig. 10b. Unlike the tortuous fractures in heterogeneous granite, hydraulic fractures in relatively homogenous sandstone are straight and fracture branching is insignificant at the core scale. Due to its high matrix permeability, fluid leak-off is significant and the initially dry specimen can achieve a high degree of saturation after several injection cycles. Fluid pressure in the sandstone matrix far away from the borehole can achieve the same magnitude of the borehole pressure. A large number of cycles does not contribute to the degree of fluid saturation because the specimen is almost saturated in the early stages of injection with a limited number of cycles (e.g., <10); instead, long-duration injection results in cementation weakening and therefore in strength degradation. Moreover, the effects of stress corrosion can play a role when using distilled water as the fracturing fluid in quartz-rich rocks. Unlike that in the granite, tensile-strength degradation by fluid saturation in porous sandstone is dominated. We recommend investigating the mutual effects of stress deviators and stress corrosion both separately and subsequently in combined tests in order to obtain more insights into the overall complex process of hydraulic fatigue in quartz-rich geothermal-reservoir target rock, such as sandstone in particular.
Relaxation damage control via hydraulic fatigue cycles not only seems to work in granite at the grain-scale (laboratory) but also has been demonstrated to work at mine scale and is a candidate for full scale field experiments in granitic rock.
18
 The basic ingredients in hydraulic fatigue testing – including variable flow rates, multiple crack resting times, and more tortuous and denser fracture-network evolutions – can be seen scale independent, although the intrinsic properties of different rocks are involved at various scales.
18
 At mine-scale, the decrease in formation breakdown pressure with number of injection cycles and a more complex fatigue fracture pattern could be confirmed in granites and granodiorite of Äspö Hard Rock Laboratory at 410 m depth.
24
 Three independent sources of information were used to estimate the fracture surface area: (1) impression packer results, (2) the stimulated volume via micro-seismicity observations, and (3) high precision tilt observations of the tunnel floor in the near-field of the in-situ fracturing experiment.
18

,

51
 We admit that more rock types need to be investigated in future also at larger scale, and each rock type may need a tailor-made cyclic, pulse and/or pneumatic injection treatment in order to increase the overall confidence in the hydraulic fatigue concept.
When comparing the results of the two granites and the sandstone employed in this study, the effect of hydraulic fatigue is more prominent in hard rock compared to weak rock, which is in line with a recent study on cement blocks having different porosities and according low and high strength.
52
 We see the combined design of short-term hydraulic stimulation and long-term creep-tests at different scales as minimum requirement to further refine our understanding of the mutual relationship and interrelation between the effect of high pressure cycles and stress corrosion in rock hydraulic fatigue behavior.


7
Conclusions
We investigated the hydraulic fracturing behavior of coarse-grained Pocheon granite and Gonghe granite and fine-grained sandstone with 9% porosity via laboratory experiments that applied monotonic and cyclic water injection. Conventional and fatigue hydraulic fracture paths were analyzed via quantitative measurements from X-ray CT scanning and collages of thin section observations. Our main findings are summarized below:

(1)
The hydraulic fracture path was significantly influenced by the composition minerals and grain size. Mode-Ⅰ cracks were mainly created in all the specimens but fracture patterns were different in the two granites with large and small grain sizes. Platy biotite grains contributed to a change in fracture orientation during propagation as well as to grain-boundary fractures. The fraction of grain-boundary fractures on the total length of bi-wing hydraulic fractures was ∼ 20% in Pocheon granite and up to 49% in Gonghe granite. Quartz gains – particularly the fractured grains caused by pre-existing flaws – contributed to intragranular fractures, for example, in Pocheon granite.


(2)
Combined with our previous findings, this study demonstrated that a maximum of a ∼ 20% reduction in breakdown pressure can be achieved by CHF compared with monotonic HF for granite. This reduction ratio is much higher than that of tensile strength degradation via full water saturation (2.6% for Pocheon granite and 10.5% for Gonghe granite). The BP reduction (15.7%) observed during CHF was much lower compared with tensile strength degradation (42.9%) induced by water saturation in the porous sandstone.


(3)
CHF can potentially reduce the maximum magnitude of acoustic emissions. The average reduction was 17.5 dB, 7.5 dB, and 4.6 dB for the Gonghe granite, Pocheon granite, and gray sandstone, respectively. The reduction effect was more significant for intact granite with lower permeability. This finding supports our hypothesis that the hydraulic fatigue process is rock-type specific. Stimulation treatments in the field, in turn, should be designed to be rock-type specific.


(4)
CHF can produce complex fracture patterns with higher fracture tortuosity. Fracture tortuosity measured at the core scale was about 1.03–1.07 in the two granites, which was slightly higher than the 1.02 measured in the sandstone. Higher tortuosity created by CHF compared with HF was found in Gonghe granite that contained a large portion (13.4%) of biotite and pre-existing flaws. Hydraulic fatigue in granites was characterized by fracture branching and activation of natural pre-existing discontinuities.



Finally, the effect of CHF was more pronounced in granite compared with in porous sandstone. Considering the purpose of reduction in both breakdown pressure and induced acoustic emissions, we therefore recommend further investigations into CHF behavior in less-permeable rock, such as granite and tight sandstone, and particularly into the mutual impact of stress deviator and stress-corrosion effects in quartz-rich rock.

Introduction
The construction of underground tunnel structures has been rapidly increasing to solve traffic congestion in urban areas.
1
 Rocks are natural materials with heterogeneous properties and pose uncertainties when subjected to excavation, owing to varied geological properties depending on the location.
2–4
 Geological hazards encountered during tunnel construction can be caused by natural factors, including ground conditions and the presence of unexpected weak zones, but also by human factors such as construction conditions and support designs,
5

,

6
 with the potential for massive losses and injuries. Therefore, it is essential to understand the engineering characteristics of the target excavation site for safe and economical underground construction.
4


Site investigations are carried out through vertical borehole drilling to estimate the in-situ underground conditions over a wide area. However, there are limits to evaluate underground structures in detail. To solve this problem, various types of geological survey techniques, such as pilot horizontal boring and tunnel seismic prediction surveys, have been adopted to estimate the subsurface conditions ahead of the tunnel face during excavation.
7–10
 However, the application of these techniques during tunnel construction requires additional steps and costs.
11


Measurement while drilling (MWD) techniques have been developed for evaluating in-situ rock mass characterization for predicting the geological conditions ahead of the tunnel face.
12
 Several studies have been conducted to investigate the geological conditions ahead of the tunnel face by pressure monitoring using a hydraulic drilling machine.
13–21
 Furthermore, many researchers have carried out studies using artificial intelligence technologies, such as machine learning, to analyze the relationships among drilling datasets, and predict geological conditions,
22–24
 concluding that MWD techniques are an objective and reliable method for assessing geological conditions ahead of the tunnel excavation face.
Large-diameter empty holes over 250 mm in diameter have been applied at the excavation face in the New Austrian Tunneling Method (NATM) tunnel to reduce blast-induced vibrations and are generally drilled to a distance of 50 m at a time in Korea.
25
 It is reported to be efficient in reducing blast-induced vibration through the formation of additional free faces
26
; however, it is time consuming because of the underdeveloped boring machines. In addition, boring operations rely on the operator's experience and not on any monitoring devices, resulting in large differences in boring quality depending on the operator's proficiency. Furthermore, it is difficult to control the boring machine in real-time in response to changes in geological conditions. Recently, a multi-setting smart-investigation of the ground and pre-large hole boring (MSP) method and machines have been developed to replace outdated existing boring machines.
27

,

28
 The high-performance MSP machine drills 382 mm diameter holes, which are 20 mm larger than those drilled by the conventional machines over a shorter construction period. Kim et al.
29
 developed a borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system to observe the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face; however, this method has the disadvantage of increasing the construction period as it requires an additional process in which equipment must be applied after drilling is completed.
In this study, a real-time boring data monitoring system for the MSP machine was developed to predict the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face without requiring additional steps. This monitoring system measures the percussion pressure, rotation pressure, feed pressure used for boring work, and boring speed. To estimate the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face, the proposed monitoring system was applied to the subway construction site where drilling was performed to a depth of 40 m. In addition, a borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system developed by the authors was used to verify the monitoring data by observing the actual geological conditions of the ground. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The characteristics of the newly proposed MSP method (a high-performance MSP machine) are introduced in Section 2. Section 3 introduces the real-time boring data monitoring system, which was newly developed for the MSP machine described, as well as a borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system used for verification of monitoring data. Data collection through field application and data analysis are presented in Sections 4 and 5, respectively. Finally, the conclusions drawn from these analyses are presented in Section 6.


2
MSP method
The proposed method called the multi-setting smart-investigation of the ground and pre-large hole boring (MSP) method, is a cut blasting method used to minimize the blast-induced vibration in the NATM tunnel by boring a large-diameter empty hole, as shown in Fig. 1
. The MSP machine, with a 382-mm hammer bit, generally drills to a distance of 50 m, and a depth of 10–60 m, depending on the requirements at the construction site. The MSP hole plays an important role in the reduction of the blast-induced vibration by releasing the confining stresses of the rock mass before blasting and the residual energy after rock breaking.
30

,

31
 These MSP holes also provide larger initial spaces for moving breaking rocks through large empty holes. In general, one to three holes are used in the MSP method, and its applicability depends on the site conditions. This method is suitable for both short-and long-hole blasting as well as weak and hard rock masses, unlike the conventional cut-blasting methods such as the V-cut and cylinder cut methods.
28


To drill to a total distance of 50 m, 5 m long rods are extended, and the MSP machine uses two types of pressure for boring: pneumatic pressure and hydraulic pressure. Pneumatic pressure is used for the percussion pressure, which generates the impact force in the rock by providing compressed air in the piston-type hammer bit. The hydraulic pressure is used as a rotation pressure to rotate the hammer bit in one direction and change the impact position after the first impact is completed. Furthermore, the rotation pressure is also used to discharge the crushed rock with high-pressure water by rotating the rods. This hydraulic pressure is also used as the feed pressure to maintain the hammer bit at an appropriate distance from the rock surface by advancing the main body. A variable displacement pump that provides the required hydraulic pressure was used for the feed pressure to respond automatically in real-time to geological changes within a given range. Fig. 2
 shows the field application of the MSP machine on a tunnel construction site.


3
MSP monitoring system for evaluating geological conditions

3.1
Real-time boring data monitoring system
A real-time boring data monitoring system mounted on the MSP machine was developed to improve the boring efficiency, as shown in Fig. 3
. The monitoring system comprises the working pressure monitoring part and the boring depth measurement part. The working pressure monitoring part measures the percussion, rotation, and feed pressures used in the boring works, and the wire sensor measures the total boring depth of the MSP machine. The 382-mm-diameter hammer bit was used to break the rock mass, and air pressure was provided by an industrial pneumatic air compressor. The measured data were recorded through a data logger over time, and transmitted to a self-developed software installed on the laptop and monitored in real-time. The sampling rate was set to 1 sampling/s because the MSP method generally continues for more than 8 h. The main specifications of the monitoring devices are summarized in Table 1
.


3.2
Boring alignment tracking and ground exploration system
A deviation in both the vertical and horizontal directions of the boring alignment occurs because of the weight of the hammer bit and rods and one-directional rotation.
27
 Furthermore, the deviation can unexpectedly increase owing to unskilled operators, machine conditions, and particular geological characteristics ahead of the excavation face. If the deviation exceeds the target position, which can be used as an empty hole in the cut area, re-construction of the MSP method is required; this leads to problems such as additional costs due to the re-entry of the boring machine and operators, thereby extending the construction period.

Fig. 4
(a) shows the borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system developed by the authors.
29
 This system measures the drilled whole path immediately after the boring, using an inertial measurement unit sensor to check the borehole alignment and determine whether re-construction is required. In addition, the geological conditions are investigated by photographing inside the drilled hole using a machine vision camera. This system can explore the inside of the holes at a total length of 70 m, and this exploration is monitored through the MSP analysis platform (MAP) in real-time, as shown in Fig. 4(b). The MAP is an integrated platform that not only shows the measured data in real-time, but also controls the exploration system and cable drum. The exploration system was used to compare the monitored boring data and actual geological conditions acquired from the exploration system. The specifications focused on the exploration part are summarized in Table 2
.



4
Field applications

4.1
Field application of the monitoring system
The proposed MSP method was applied to numerous tunnel construction sites in Korea to minimize blast-induced vibrations. At the same time, the real-time boring data monitoring system equipped with the MSP machine was used to estimate the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face at 10 tunnel construction sites, more than 30 times in addition to the test sites. In this study, a significant example among the several cases that the interpreted information report has provided crucial support throughout the main tunnel construction was introduced.

Fig. 5
 shows the original boring datasets obtained from the North Gyeongsang region in Korea. The MSP method was applied to a distance of 40 m with one hole, after consultation with the contractor, to reduce the blast-induced vibration in an area mainly composed of granitic gneiss. Fig. 5 shows the interface of the software for the boring data monitoring system, which can be used on a laptop or tablet PC. This monitoring data comprises the measured percussion pressure, rotation pressure, feed pressure, and boring depth from the top. The monitoring software displays the boring data in real-time, allowing instantaneous responses to unexpected situations during boring work by monitoring the boring process.


4.2
Comparison of monitoring data and observed images

Fig. 6
(a) shows the monitoring data focused on the first-rod data corresponding to 0–5 m out of a total depth of 40 m. There are four types of data, that is, rotation pressure, feed pressure, percussion pressure, and boring speed data and the boring speed was calculated from the boring depth over time. The boring data from 0 to 270 s show the pressures required to stabilize the initial planned drilling position on the rough tunnel face through manual operation. Starting at 270 s, the data show the monitoring data after the hammer bit was set in the target position and stabilized. After boring stabilization, the pressures are generally not controlled manually unless an unexpected symptom is detected. According to the monitoring data, most of the pressure data showed similar trends at a constant level; however, in section B (900–1050 s), the rotation pressure and boring speed increased abnormally. Although for percussion using air pressure, no particular correlation was found compared to other hydraulic pressure data. It is thought that the percussion pressure provided by the industrial compressor is immediately released after the piston operation of the hammer bit.
To determine the geological conditions, a borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system was used. Images are typically extracted at intervals of 1 m from the video; however, the images in Fig. 6(b) were manually extracted for a more detailed analysis. The boring data and extracted images for section A corresponding to 1.80 m indicate general geological conditions over moderately hard rock. However, according to section B corresponding to 2.70 m, there was a fractured zone as expected in this area.

Fig. 7
(a) shows the monitoring data focused on the second rod corresponding to 5–10 m. The data from 0 to 200 s show large variations for both rotation and feed pressures compared to other data; the data in Section C were decreased in rotation and feed pressures as opposed to the pattern in Section B in Fig. 6. It was predicted that there would be highly fractured zones in the area because manual operation for setting the hammer bit at the target position was not required after the first rod. In addition, it is assumed that there are weak zones in the area for 800–900 s.



5
Discussion

5.1
Pre-processing of the boring data
The MSP method is essentially accompanied by non-continuous forms of boring data, as shown in Fig. 5. This is due to the temporary interruption of boring for the extension of the 5 m rod. These irregular data forms cause difficulties in the continuous analysis of geological conditions. To continuously analyze the original data, manual pre-processing work should be carried out to convert the data to a continuous data form, which requires a considerable amount of time. Therefore, a pre-processing program that automatically connects all boring data continuously by removing the rod replacement or a work stoppage section was developed in Python. Therefore, the Pre-MSP software can significantly reduce the data pre-processing time, which greatly helps in data analysis, and Fig. 8
 shows the interface of the pre-processing program. In addition, the boring data usually accompany the noises under constant pressures; it is estimated to be the composition of the minerals of the rock or micro-cracks inside the rocks, as shown in Figs. 6 and 7. The pre-processing program provides two types of interpolation, fast Fourier transform and linear regression, for efficient data processing.

Fig. 9
 shows the entire preprocessed boring data corresponding to 0–40 m. This graph shows the feed pressure, rotation pressure, boring depth, and boring speed over time. In this graph, there are three remarkable sections marked in red squares that show pressure and speed data with unusual changes. In all sections, the rotation pressure and feed pressure decreased rapidly with increasing boring speed. It is presumed that these changes are due to the presence of fractured zones, which are crushed more easily than other rocks. According to the boring data analysis in Section 4, the areas corresponding to approximately 5.0–6.5 m, 10.0–11.5 m, and 15.0–16.5 m can be estimated to have highly fractured zones. In addition, the boring speed indicated by the length of the arrows at the top of the graph can be crucial for analyzing the conditions of the rock mass ahead of the excavation face. According to the boring speed, it is possible to estimate relatively weak zones compared to other areas.


5.2
Analysis of relationship between boring parameters and geological conditions

Fig. 10
 depicts the three possible cases that can occur inside a hole during MSP boring, and Table 3
 summarizes several relationships derived from the boring data in Fig. 9. For the hammer bit used in the MSP machine, it is important to maintain the distance in the range of 2–5 cm between the hammer bit and rock surface to maximize the impact energy, as shown in Fig. 10(a). Maintaining a proper distance provides a stable boring environment; thus, pressures and boring speed are maintained at a constant level, as shown in case 1 in Table 3. However, actual boring work is carried out in unpredictable and irregular environments owing to the heterogeneous characteristics of the rock. Therefore, it is continuously faced in inappropriate boring environments as shown in Figs. 10(b) and (c). If the distance between the hammer bit and the rock becomes too small, as shown in Fig. 10(b), the feed pressure increases, and the crushing efficiency may decrease because the minimum distance is not satisfied. In addition, the excessively high feed pressure relative to the rock crushing speed causes the damage to the hammer bit, a critical component, and prolongs the construction period. Therefore, boring work is usually performed under conservative feed pressure to prevent such situations, as shown in Fig. 10(b), and data with increasing feed pressure cannot be found in the entire boring dataset. Fig. 10(c) also shows an inappropriate distance caused by low feed pressure or easily drilled fractured zones, and cases 2–4 in Table 3 correspond to this environment in the MSP boring process. The rotation pressures show opposite tendencies in cases 2 and 3, as shown in Figs. 6 and 7. It has been reported that the rotation pressure generally decreases with increasing boring speed in weak zones.
32

,

33
 On the other hand, in some cases, the rotation pressure can increase in the fractured zones with very low rock quality designation (RQD) values.
16

,

34
 In the MSP boring, the rotation pressure can decrease as the overbreak zones increase owing to the presence of the fractured zones (weak zones), and also can temporarily increase as the amount of fine crushed rock (sludge) increases. Thus, it was estimated that the rotation pressure is more dependent on the degree of fragmentation of rocks encountered during boring, however, it is evident that rapid changes in the rotation pressure and boring speed are typically observed in the fractured zones. The rotation pressure data might be used only to infer the existence of the fractured zones and their intensity. Although it is difficult to determine the ground conditions ahead of the excavation face only based on the rotation pressure, more accurate analysis was possible through the combination with other boring data.


5.3
Comparison of boring time and geological conditions

Fig. 11
 shows the total boring time for each rod derived from the monitored boring data. The first rod took approximately 26 min, which was longer than that taken by the other rods, to drill 5 m. As mentioned above, this is because boring was carried out slowly to properly align the target position of the hammer bit from the rough surface. In this graph, the average boring time is approximately 17.07 min except for the first rod; the maximum and minimum boring times corresponding to the fifth and seventh rods, respectively, varied by up to 1.63 times. Based on the boring time, it could be assumed that the fifth rod, corresponding to the 25–30 m section, is in a weak or fractured zone compared to other areas.
Based on the total boring time for each rod in Fig. 11, hole images were extracted corresponding to the fifth and seventh rods (Fig. 12
), which had the minimum and maximum boring times, respectively, to compare the geological conditions inside the hole. Fig. 12(a) shows the images of the fifth rod, which had the minimum boring time. As shown in Fig. 12(a), highly fractured zones were observed in this area as well as in many joint sets; thus, the boring time was significantly reduced compared to other sections. On the other hand, although there are sections from 32.40 to 33.30 m and from 34.20 to 35.10 m where the boring speed is rapidly accelerated due to fractured zones, Fig. 12(b) generally shows relatively fresh rocks compared to those in Fig. 12(a). Therefore, it is evident that the boring speed for each rod can be used for estimating the rock mass conditions for each section.


5.4
Classification of geological conditions using the MSP monitoring system
The original feed pressure, rotation pressure, percussion pressure, and boring speed data were processed using differentiation to analyze the variation over time, as shown in Fig. 13
. The images show the differential data for each monitoring dataset as well as the original data, and negative values for each processed data were converted using absolute values. The variations in feed pressure and boring speed over time, as shown in Figs. 13(a) and (b), were observed to be relatively noticeable according to geological conditions. In addition, the feed pressure and boring speed showed a relatively high correlation in the variation over time, particularly in the highly fractured zones. Meanwhile, the variation of the rotation pressure, as shown in Fig. 13(c), showed a relatively low correlation with the geological changes compared to the feed pressure and boring speed, and it is estimated that the rotation pressure has a greater influence on the pressure required for rotation of the rods depending on the amount of crushed rocks during MSP boring. In the section where the variation of the rotation pressure is greater than 3 bar, the feed pressure and boring speed generally increase; thus, the variation in the rotation pressure only helps to estimate the geological changes, but it is difficult to establish the classification criteria in three stages. On the other hand, for the percussion pressure, as shown in Fig. 13(d), no correlation was found with the geological changes, and it is estimated that the compressive air supplied to the hammer bit is discharged immediately after being used for piston operation.
Based on the images shown in Figs. 7 and 12, the variations in the feed pressure and boring speed over time, geological conditions were classified into three stages: fresh zones, moderately fractured zones, and highly fractured zones, as shown in Figs. 13(a) and (b). The green and orange sections represent relatively fresh and moderately fractured zones, respectively, whereas the red section appears to be a highly fractured zone. The variations in the boring speed and feed pressure rapidly increased up to approximately 0.0055

Based on the overall assessment of the section, it can be seen that the highly fractured zones were mainly distributed between 5 and 17 m of the site, and fresh zones and moderately fractured zones existed in the 17–40 m sections. Based on these relationships, it is confirmed that the MSP monitoring system can classify the geological conditions beyond the excavation face according to the changes in feed pressure and boring speed; the proposed method for geological classification ahead of the excavation face using the MSP boring data monitoring system is shown in Table 4
.
As mentioned above, the proposed MSP boring data monitoring system was applied at the various tunnel construction sites more than 30 times in Korea. As a result of the continuous acquisition and analysis of the monitored data, although there were some differences in each pressure data from site to site, the variations for the pressures over time and boring speed generally showed a similar tendency for most datasets. In addition, continuous acquisition of additional data and analysis are essential to develop an advanced geological classification system that can cover various types of rock. The MSP boring data monitoring system has been continuously applied to the various road and subway tunnel construction sites to further optimize the ground classification system. Furthermore, a Python-based automatic assessment system to improve its applicability have developed based on the collected data. This integrated data acquisition and interpretation system will not only rapidly carry out the pre-processing when the obtained MSP boring data is input but also allow the automatic analysis of geological conditions by analyzing the variations of the pressures and boring speed. In addition, this system will enable reasonable geological assessment even with inexperienced engineers.
The finally interpreted boring data is provided to the constructor in the form of reports. The data interpretation reports contain original factual boring data (before pre-processing), processed factual boring data, as well as interpretation of the processed monitoring results, and prediction of the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face. Based on the interpretation reports about the local geology, tunnel constructors can update their design regarding blasting patterns for tunnel excavation as well as the rock supports for the main tunnel construction. This MSP boring data monitoring system has been continuously applied to each tunnel construction sites for their safety and construction management throughout the tunneling projects.



6
Conclusions
In this study, a real-time boring data monitoring system, using the MSP boring machine to drill a large-diameter empty hole, was newly developed to evaluate the geological conditions ahead of the tunnel excavation face. The proposed MSP monitoring system was applied to the subway tunnel construction site to predict the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face, corresponding to a distance of 40 m. In addition, the borehole alignment tracking and ground exploration system which can observe the geological conditions inside large-diameter empty holes was used to compare the boring data and geological conditions. The main conclusions drawn from this study are as follows:

●
According to the analysis results of the monitored boring data and empty hole images, the feed pressure and boring speed showed a relatively high correlation as the geological conditions changed. In particular, the variation in the feed pressure and boring speed was more than 10 bar/s, and 0.003 

m
/

s
2


, respectively, in the highly fractured zones. The variation in the rotation pressure could help to estimate the geological changes, but it is difficult to classify the geological conditions into three stages because the rotation pressure is more reliant on the amount of crushed rocks during boring using the rotation pressure. On the other hand, the percussion pressure was not found to be related to geological changes because the compressive air was released immediately after the piston operation of the hammer bit.


●
There was a disadvantage in that the discontinuous data formed due to the rod extension work requiring pre-processing to continuously analyze the geological conditions. To address this drawback, the Pre-MSP software, which performs pre-processing of the MSP boring data, was developed to improve the efficiency of data analysis by minimizing complexity and inconvenience. This software makes it possible to predict the overall geological conditions immediately without manual pre-processing.


●
According to the monitored boring data, the boring time for each rod varied by up to 1.63 times. Comparing the geological conditions of the two zones that showed the maximum and minimum boring speeds, it was found that there were relatively large fractured zones in the section where the boring speed rapidly increased. Therefore, the MSP boring speed can be used as a basis for estimating the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face.


●
Based on the boring data and observed hole image data, a new classification method for estimating the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face, using the MSP boring data monitoring system, was proposed in three stages. The proposed MSP boring data monitoring system with the Pre-MSP software has great advantages in predicting the geological conditions ahead of the excavation face, without additional techniques or construction processes. In addition, if multi-MSP with two or more holes is applied to increase the vibration reduction efficiency, a more reliable and accurate prediction of geological conditions will be possible through the integrated analysis of monitoring data for several adjacent MSP holes.


●
However, continuous acquisition of additional data and analysis are essential to develop an advanced geological classification system that can integrate various types of rocks. The proposed MSP boring data monitoring system has been continuously applied to the various tunnel construction sites to develop the advanced ground classification system. Moreover, a Python-based automatic assessment system have developed by our research team to improve its applicability on the construction site. This advanced geological classification system will not only rapidly perform the pre-processing of the MSP boring data but also allow the automatic evaluation of geological conditions beyond the excavation face. In addition, this system will enable reasonable ground evaluation even for inexperienced engineers and help enhance safety and efficiency during tunnel construction.

Introduction and literature review
Studies of stress in granular material have been carried out for many years due to this material's importance in many industries (i.e. Food, Pharmacy, Mining
1–3
). In block cave mining, the granular material is composed of large rock fragments within a broken column of hundreds of meters. Thus, a soil mechanics approach has been proposed to estimate stress in the caved column,
4–7

8
 as an initial stress estimation. Nevertheless, the stress modelling of a broken column is more complex when different rock types, draw strategies, and complex cave geometries have to be considered.
A common tool used to study complex granular media problems is the distinct element method (DEM;
9

10–17
). DEM has also been used in mining studies.
18–21
 However, in cave mining studies,
19–21

As an example in Ref. 21, a draw simulation of a cylindrical model of 0.7 m height and 0.34 m diameter takes between a week and a month to complete. Other numerical tools are used for large scale problems that quickly simulate the ore flow without considering dynamic interaction between particles, such as PCBC,

6
Conclusions
In this work, a stress model is presented to simulate vertical stress in granular materials using a CA. The CA used allows gravity flow to be simulated quickly and precisely in large scale models as required by cave mining. Then, the stress in static and dynamic flow conditions can be simulated at large scale when modeled though a gravity flow simulator based on CA. The proposed stress model was calibrated with different experiments at laboratory scale in which a high level of accuracy was observed for different material media and model geometries in static conditions. The parameter E is constant for the same type of material, problem geometry and mesh selected (cell sizes). However, this parameter increased when the height of the model is increased as in cave mining during caving propagation. The stress model also simulated flow conditions through the parameters R and E

min
. These parameters were calibrated and compared under different flow scenarios, showing good results based on the expected variability of the experimental setup used. Then, our vertical stress model with the flow simulator based on CA has the potential to be applied at block caving scale once the model parameters are defined.

1
Introduction
An important part of the performance and safety assessment of disposal systems for radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel in deep geological formations is the evaluation of the impact of the coupled effects of mechanical deformation, fluid and gas flow through the repository, and thermal loading from the decaying waste. It was recognized early on in safety and performance assessments conducted for geologic disposal sites that to be able to conduct such an evaluation, there was a need to rigorously enhance the theoretical background and to develop models capable of simulating coupled thermo-hydro-mechanical (THM) processes. More recently, chemical (C) processes have also been added to enable the study of fully coupled THMC processes in geosystems.
The term “coupled processes” implies that each process potentially affects and is affected by the initiation and progress of other processes. Thus, the response of a rock mass to radioactive waste storage cannot be predicted with confidence by considering each process individually or in direct succession. In the field of rock mechanics and rock engineering, many studies have been made on two-way coupling (e.g., TM and HM), but for the repository performance problem, it is essential to study and be able to give reasonable assurance of the prediction of processes with THM coupling, and even full THMC coupling. Such coupling remains a major challenge to the science and engineering community, in part because relevant effects need to be better understood and described with constitutive relations, but also since the processes have widely different characteristic temporal and spatial scales. Coupled processes of course are not only relevant to geologic disposal of radioactive waste but also play a critical role in a range of other sub-surface engineering activities, such as carbon dioxide sequestration, enhanced geothermal systems, energy storage, as well as unconventional oil and gas production through hydraulic stimulation.
In 1992, recognizing the need to address the modeling challenges related to coupled THM and (in later stages) THMC processes, DECOVALEX was initiated as an international cooperative project of nuclear waste organizations, including implementers, regulators, and research institutions, plus a large number of associated research and modeling teams, providing a wide range of perspectives and solutions to these complex problems (www.decovalex.org). Analysis and comparative modeling of state-of-the-art field and laboratory experiments has been at the core of the collaborative work, with an increasing focus on characterizing uncertainty and blind prediction of experimental results. Since 1992, the project has gone through several four-year phases, each phase featuring a number of selected modeling challenges of importance to radioactive waste disposal. Six project phases were successfully concluded between 1992 and 2015, results of which have been summarized in several overview publications (e.g. Refs.
1–3
) and in a series of Special Issues in the International Journal of Rock Mechanics and Mining Sciences (Vol. 32(5) in 1995, Vol. 38(1) in 2001, and Vol. 42(5–6) in 2005), in the Journal of Environmental Geology (Vol. 57(6) in 2009), and in the Journal of Environmental Earth Sciences (Virtual Topical Collection, 2016).
The 7th phase of the DECOVALEX project, here referred to as DECOVALEX-2019, comprised of modeling teams from 13 international partner organizations, which participated in the comparative evaluation of seven modeling tasks (i.e., Tasks A through G). Together, these tasks address a wide range of relevant issues related to engineered and natural system behavior in a variety of potential host rocks. The 29 publications in this Virtual Special Issue provide an in-depth overview of the collaborative research efforts conducted in each task and how these have advanced the state-of-the-art of understanding and modeling coupled THMC processes. Below, we briefly introduce each task, provide references to respective publications, and explore some common lessons learned that have emerged across the tasks. One of the most important characteristics of DECOVALEX is the emphasis on a cooperative research environment and the desire to gain insight by comparative analysis of multiple alternative approaches. This characteristic is reflected in this Virtual Special Issue by jointly authored synthesis papers for each task. These provide an overview of the modeling approaches pursued by individual research teams and discuss which concepts and models have been particularly suited for a given coupled problem. The synthesis papers are supplemented by more detailed publications describing the research methods and findings of individual teams.


2
DECOVALEX-2019 tasks
The seven DECOVALEX-2019 tasks can be grouped into the four following general themes:

-
Novel Representations of Micro-Scale Processes (Tasks A and F)


-
THM Processes in Clay-Based Materials (Tasks D and E)


-
Modeling Coupled Processes in Complex Fracture Networks (Tasks C and G)


-
Complex Hydro-Mechanics with Relevance for Broader Subsurface Engineering Applications (Task B)



The tasks under each theme are discussed below.

2.1
Novel representations of micro-scale processes

2.1.1
Task A: ENGINEER - modeling advective gas flow in low permeability sealing materials
The purpose of Task A was to better understand the processes governing gas migration in low permeability clay-based barrier materials (Fig. 1
). Special attention was given to the fundamental mechanisms and controlling factors for gas migration, such as gas entry and flow, or pathway stability and sealing, which will affect barrier performance. The modeling task utilized a series of well-instrumented small-scale laboratory experiments that were conducted by the British Geological Survey (BGS). Task participants tested new model concepts in comparison to a variety of tests that were conducted under different conditions and dimensionalities, including 1D and pseudo-spherical gas flow at constant volume and constant stress. Eight international modeling teams participated in ENGINEER using four types of modeling approaches: (i) standard two-phase flow models incorporating a range of different mechanical deformation behaviors, (ii) enhanced two-phase flow models in which fractures are embedded within a plastic material (continuous techniques) or incorporated into the model using a rigid-body-spring network (discrete approaches), (iii) a single-phase model incorporating a creep damage function in which only gas flow is considered, and (iv) a conceptual approach used to examine the chaotic nature of gas flow. A summary of the collaborative research work conducted in this DECOVALEX task is given in the synthesis paper by Tamayo-Mas et al.
4
 Detailed results from individual modeling groups can be found in Chittenden et al.
5
; Dagher et al.
6
, Damians et al.
7
; Kim et al.
8
; and Harrington et al.
9




2.1.2
Task F: FINITO - fluid inclusion and movement in the tight rock
The purpose of this modeling task was to refine and compare modeling approaches for the behavior of fluid inclusions in tight low-permeability rock (Fig. 2
). Fluid inclusions may be found within mineral crystals or along grain boundaries in evaporitic formations as well as in many sedimentary rocks and can migrate in the presence of thermal or hydro-mechanical gradients. For the disposal of radioactive waste, common host rock candidates such as clay and salt rock are considered tight with respect to fluid movement and such fluid inclusions are typically stagnant. However, they may become mobilized by a perturbation of the in situ state, which can occur due to excavation and other geotechnical installations, the emplacement of heat-generating waste, or the generation of gas pressure. The migration of fluid inclusions can have important impacts on the long-term performance of a geologic repository for high-level radioactive waste disposal. Task F was designed to investigate two aspects of fluid inclusion migration in rock salt under different boundary conditions: (a) altered hydro-mechanical conditions as a consequence of tunnel excavation or borehole drilling and (b) coupled thermo-hydro-mechanical-chemical conditions during the heating period in the post-closure phase of a repository. The three teams involved in this task collaborated to improve process understanding and model concept development. Aspects of the research work conducted in Task F are given in Shao et al.
11





2.2
THM processes in clay-based materials

2.2.1
Task D: INBEB - hydro-mechanical (HM) and THM Interactions in Bentonite Engineered Barriers
The objective of INBEB (Interactions in Bentonite Engineered Barriers) was the interpretation and modeling of the performance of an initially inhomogeneous bentonite barrier, based on data from two full-scale long-term experiments. These are the isothermal Engineered Barrier (EB) experiment (Fig. 3
), which ran for over ten years at the Mont Terri URL, and the non-isothermal FEBEX heater test, which was in operation for more than 18 years at the Grimsel Test Site. In both cases, a comprehensive post-experiment dismantling and characterization effort provided uniquely detailed three-dimensional information of the bentonite barrier properties at the end of each test. INBEB assessed the evolution from a newly installed unsaturated engineered system to a fully functioning barrier, using HM and THM model predictions in comparison to the experimental data. Special attention was paid to the evolution of barrier heterogeneity under transient conditions and on the final state reached upon saturation. This requires improved constitutive relationships to describe material behavior and properties in hydrating bentonite, an enhanced understanding of the fundamental processes that lead to barrier homogenization, and improved capabilities for modeling coupled HM and THM processes in complex geo-materials. Four international research teams participated in INBEB. In general, the numerical models were able to represent adequately the trends in the observed TH and THM behavior modelled. A summary of the collaborative research work conducted in this task is given in the synthesis paper of Gens et al.
13
 Further details from individual teams are given in Lee et al.
14
; Takayama
15
; and Michalec.
16




2.2.2
Task E: upscaling of heater test modeling results
The purpose of this modeling task was to evaluate upscaling approaches for THM modeling in the Callovo-Oxfordian (COx) claystone host rock, starting with small size experiments (some cubic meters) to real scale emplacement cells (some ten cubic meters) all the way to scale of a waste repository (cubic kilometers). To achieve this aim, Task E utilized data from in-situ heating experiments performed by Andra (the French National Radioactive Waste Management Agency) in the Meuse/Haute-Marne Underground Research Laboratory (MHM URL). The repository design developed by Andra assumes that waste canisters are placed horizontally in parallel micro-tunnels drilled from access drifts. A comprehensive research program was conducted in the Meuse/Haute-Marne URL near Bure to investigate the THM response of the COx to thermal loading from these microtunnels, through laboratory and in-situ experiments. The in-situ experimental program consists of a step-by-step approach ranging from small-scale heating boreholes (TED experiment) to a full-scale experiment of a single emplacement tunnel (ALC experiment - Fig. 4
). Task E started with modeling of the TED experiment to derive THM parameters by means of a calibration exercise and then used these parameters for a blind prediction of the ALC experiment. As a final modeling step, the models tested against the ALC data were extrapolated to a model for the entire repository with multiple emplacement tunnels. Five teams participated in Task E. A summary of the collaborative research work conducted in this Task is given in two synthesis papers, the first by Seyedi et al.
