2.3
Modeling coupled processes in complex fracture networks

2.3.1
Task C: GREET - modeling hydro-mechanical-chemical-biological processes during groundwater recovery in crystalline rock
Task C centered on the GREET test, a full-scale experiment recently conducted in the Japanese Mizunami URL (crystalline rock) to evaluate the natural resaturation of the near-field environment of a geologic repository after repository closure (Fig. 5
). GREET stands for Groundwater REcovery Experiment in a Tunnel. The goals of GREET were as follows: (1) to understand the water recovery processes and mechanisms of the near-field fractured rock, (2) to verify coupled hydrological-mechanical and chemical simulation methods for modeling these processes, and (3) to develop monitoring techniques for the facility closure phase and appropriate closure methods taking recovery processes into account. The primary features of interest to be modelled in Task C were the water pressure drawdown and recovery, and the variation of water chemistry during the tunnel excavation and closure, as observed in the monitoring boreholes and the closure test drift (CTD) itself. Three modeling teams used a range of deterministic and stochastic approaches to represent how high-permeability fracture pathways near the tunnel impact groundwater recovery and water chemistry. Onoe et al.
30
 and Hokr & Balvin
31
 describe modeling activities conducted for DECOVALEX Task C.


2.3.2
Task G: EDZ evolution: reliability, feasibility, and significance of measurements of conductivity and transmissivity of the rock mass
The formation and evolution of the excavation disturbed and excavation damage zone (EDZ) around deposition tunnels and holes is an important topic in the development of radioactive waste disposal concepts. In crystalline host rock, the formation of an EDZ will increase the transmissivity of the rock mass in the vicinity of the excavations and thus raise the potential for fluid migration parallel to the excavations. Task G was primarily concerned with modeling the evolution of EDZ transmissivity throughout the lifetime of a repository from construction to pre-closure and post-closure phases. A secondary focus was on the challenges and uncertainties for monitoring rock mass permeability as a function of time during construction and operation of a repository hosted in fractured crystalline rock. The task was based on detailed EDZ transmissivity tests performed in the TAS04 tunnel in the Äspö Hard Rock Laboratory in Sweden (Fig. 6
). A summary of the collaborative research work conducted in this DECOVALEX task is given in Meier and Backers
32
 and modeling of fracture transmissivity changes in response to excavation, thermoshearing, and glaciation is presented in Kwon and Min
33
.



2.4
Complex hydro-mechanics with relevance for broader subsurface engineering applications

2.4.1
Task B: modeling the induced slip of a fault in argillaceous rock
This modeling task evaluated the conditions for slip activation and stability of faults in clay formations, with focus on the complex coupling between fault slip, pore pressure, permeability creation, and fluid migration. This subject is of great importance to many subsurface applications where injection of fluids leads to pore-pressure increase and reduction of effective normal stress on faults, which in turn can cause fault reactivation. Regarding radioactive waste emplacement, increases in pore pressure could be due to release of heat from the high-level waste or the generation of gas due to metal corrosion. The possibility of an increased permeability caused by fault slip is of concern for the long-term safety of a repository. The central element of this Task B was the FS Fault Slip Experiment conducted in the Mont Terri Underground Research Laboratory in Switzerland, which utilized a novel experimental setup for controlled fault slip testing in a realistic underground setting at field scale (Fig. 7
). Six modeling teams participated in this task, using both interface approaches or solid finite elements to account for the fault discontinuity. In general, the hydromechanical behavior of the fault as observed in the field was captured best as a propagating rupture along an existing weakness plane with damage-enhanced permeability. A summary of the collaborative research work conducted in this DECOVALEX task is given in the synthesis paper by Rutqvist et al.
35
; with further details provided in Park et al.
36
 and Shiu et al.
37






3
Main achievements and remaining challenges
DECOVALEX-2019 successfully explored some common themes across a range of complex modeling tasks (see further discussion of themes below), yielding new insights but also encountering common issues that remain to be resolved. Significant progress was achieved by research teams of all tasks. Modeling teams adopted advanced modeling approaches using different numerical methods and computer codes and were generally able to achieve good agreement, both compared to the experimental observations and compared to other teams using alternative modeling approaches. In cases where differences remain, task leads and modeling teams made efforts to isolate the reasons for them and discussed what could be done to improve. Overall, the achievements and outstanding issues obtained from the seven tasks form an important step forward for better understanding of the scientific/technical issues of importance for safe geological disposal of radioactive wastes in different host rocks, with complex geological conditions and increasing environmental challenges.

3.1
Novel representations of micro-scale processes
Both Tasks A and F both dealt with fundamental challenges in understanding and modeling the highly non-linear fluid migration observed in very low permeability formations. Observed experimental and field behaviors are often strongly stochastic and therefore it can be very difficult to rationalize the core physical behavior (i.e., identify what experimental features are reproducible under different circumstances) and successfully interpret the experiments. In addition, the experimental setup can be very important in determining the result, hence careful representation of the experiment (e.g., explicit representation of the injector apparatus used in the laboratory experiments in Task A) can be key to building a successful model. In this context, the DECOVALEX working model of close integration between experiment and modeling is an important one. In Task A, the primary concern was the migration of pressurized gas in compacted bentonite, while Task F mainly considered migration of inclusions in salt formations. While superficially quite distinct, there are a number of commonalities. For Task A, it was shown that conventional two-phase flow approaches are largely inadequate to represent the observed behavior, taking into account all the known features of the experimental results (e.g., very low gas saturations at breakthrough). Hence the inclusion of implicit or explicit features to represent the dilation process is essential. Similarly, for Task F, explicit treatment of fluid migration along the halite grain boundaries, also by a dilation process under strongly deviatoric stress conditions, was found to be a good representation of salt inclusion migration. Both tasks illustrated the importance of micro-scale control on macro-scale phenomena and novel approaches for bringing the micro-scale understanding into the meso- and macro-scale have been put forward.


3.2
THM processes in clay-based materials
Tasks D and E considered HM and THM processes in clays or clay-based materials such as bentonite or clay, at the waste disposal scale. Task E demonstrated that good blind predictions of pore-pressure and temperature can be obtained for heat-generating disposal analogs using thermal diffusion models with conventional elastic poro-mechanics. There was some evidence of surprising local heterogeneity in the clay at the MHM URL which meant some recalibration was required when moving between experiments, illustrating the potential impact of variability and heterogeneity on pore pressure. The teams were also able to upscale their models to represent the whole repository, and use these models to investigate the sensitivity of uncertainty and variability on key metrics (pore pressure and implied effective stress) that could impact the safety case. In understanding the details of the experiments, it was clear that the development of the EDZ, and the resulting effective hydraulic and mechanical properties of the EDZ, were important to calibrate the models to the observations. While the task demonstrated a generally good representation of scale-dependent THM processes, the treatment of mechanical damage and the resulting change in the clay properties remain areas of significant uncertainty. Task D focused on compacted and pelleted bentonite used as a clay-based buffer material. While teams were also able to obtain good agreement with the measured thermal and hydraulic responses, a complete representation of the plastic deformation – in this case focused on the homogenization of the bentonite during heating and resaturation – remained challenging. Hence both tasks encountered similar issues in terms of the treatment of the plasticity of clays, albeit from different perspectives (homogenization in Task D, induced damage in Task E). These issues with damage/plasticity represent the major uncertainties in the work to date and hence areas for future investigation to improve the robustness of understanding.


3.3
Modeling coupled processes in complex fracture networks
Tasks C and G both dealt with the problem of interpreting groundwater flows and (in the case of Task C) transport within discrete fracture networks (DFNs) in crystalline host rock. This is an area of long-standing study within DECOVALEX and the tasks have encountered many of same issues, albeit from a different perspective. Both tasks illustrated that realistic DFN models, based on geological observation, can successfully represent net tunnel inflows after some calibration. Some teams were also successful when using an equivalent continuum porous medium (EPCM) approach rather than a DFN model. However, both tasks ran into modeling challenges when looking at more complex aspects of the problem. In the case of Task C, successfully modeling the wide range of observed chloride concentrations in the tunnel was particularly problematic. Producing a convincing representation of the transport required manual intervention in the DFN/EPCM to connect the excavated tunnel to vertically distant higher and lower concentrations of chloride. Task G showed a similar issue at a much smaller scale, whereby the interference tests in the TAS04 experiment were very hard to interpret and model when using intersections of planar fracture surfaces identified in the EDZ. Both tasks concluded that channelization with the fracture network could be the cause of the difficulties in modeling the observations, noting that large scale heterogeneities in the DFN network for Task C could also be a factor.


3.4
Complex hydro-mechanics with relevance for broader subsurface engineering applications
Task B focused on an individual fault zone in a low-permeability claystone rather than DFN systems in a crystalline potential host rock as discussed above. Modeling teams addressed numerical challenges associated with fluid injection and reactivation in a fault system with a complex structure comprising of a strongly foliated fault core enveloped by a fractured damage zone. The task used data from a highly instrumented in situ test which provides valuable insights into the complex relationship between pressure buildup, fault opening, fault slip, and fluid migration. The collaborative modeling work in Task B clearly illustrated the numerical complexities of simulating complex discontinuous features experiencing normal and shear displacement under hydraulic control. Different numerical methods were found to have contrasting strengths and weaknesses in representing the highly non-linear nature of the hydro-mechanical response. Extensive work on an initial benchmarking exercise provided coherence between the modeling tools and gave good confidence that the basic couplings were being represented properly. However, large differences were seen between modeling approaches in more complex cases where plastic damage on shear features is suspected to play an important role. This has parallels with the DFN work where the presence of stochasticity is important. Task B is of interest outside of the radioactive waste management arena, being of direct relevance to other sub-surface engineering applications (e.g., geologic carbon sequestration, geothermal energy, underground energy storage, etc.).



4
Conclusions
The results of the collaborative modeling in DECOVALEX-2019 have produced some clear outcomes and common issues across a diverse portfolio of complex modeling task. There have been considerable successes in moving forward the science of predicting coupled processes in geological materials, but there remain non-trivial issues that are of direct relevance to a wide range of geo-engineering applications.
The work has shown that true blind predictions remain one of the best methods of building confidence in modeling approaches. Success has been had in low permeability systems predicting THM responses. However, it is necessary to consider the input uncertainty when making predictions, especially if outcomes of interest are broadly linear (e.g., pressure response) whereas the key uncertainties and log-normally distributed (e.g., intrinsic permeability). Significant progress has also made in modeling advective movement of gas in clays, with a range of 1D/2D/3D models being used successfully to give a reasonable representation of the experimental observations. It is clear from this work that a conventional continuum multi-phase flow representation of gas migration is not an appropriate method; rather alternative approaches or major augmentations of existing methods are required to produce physically plausible models. This is an area of ongoing research which is being continued in the ongoing DECOVALEX-2023 Project phase.
Science challenges around stochasticity were felt in several tasks. The time-series stochastic features in some experimental observations cause considerable difficulties in attempting to represent the experiment using essentially deterministic models. While it can be argued that a stochastic system should be modelled using a stochastic model, when only single or small numbers of experiments are available, modelers are effectively forced to use deterministic representations to understand the fundamental processes, with the treatment of the observed stochasticity a future research area. Some success was achieved using chaotic representations to understand such data, but these methods are very much in their infancy. A few modeling teams also tackled the reverse problem where stochastic models were used to condition against deterministic data for fractured rock representations. From this work there was clear evidence that details of flow and transport are not well represented using parallel plate square or circular fractures; channels or pipes appear necessary to explain experimental observations.
The representation of HM processes in large fracture systems was generally successful, but there was a heavy divergence in results dependent on the details of the numerical method used. This makes application of these models in a predictive mode difficult and the results subject to considerable uncertainty. In addition, the representation of plasticity and damage in clay rocks remains a key uncertainty and is difficult to model as an emergent phenomenon.
We hope that the brief summary presented above, and the in-depth research findings in the selected papers, provide an idea of the breadth and depth of cutting-edge research work carried out within the DECOVALEX-2019 project. With this Virtual Special Issue, we also intend to convey to interested readers the value of the DECOVALEX philosophy of cooperation between international researchers of different disciplines using a range of different approaches. Such collaboration means frequent interactions, sharing of data and results, collectively generating new ideas and concepts, raising technical issues in joint communications, and performing critical reviews of each other's work. The insight obtained in such integrated cooperative efforts would have been impossible if the teams had worked independently. Comparison of model results with other international modeling groups, using their own simulation tools and conceptual understanding, enhances confidence in the robustness of predictive models used for performance assessment. In addition, the possibility of linking model differences to particular choices in conceptual model setup provides valuable guidance into “best” modeling choices and understanding the effect of conceptual models on predictions.

Introduction
Rockbursts often occur in deep underground mines and deep tunnels where the in situ rock stresses are high. This phenomenon causes significant risk in subsurface operations and could potentially lead to personnel casualties, equipment damage, and delay of excavation operations. Systematic studies of rockburst behavior were carried out in Canada and South Africa as early as the 1940s and 1950s.

,

2
 In particular, Ortlepp
3
 visited many rockburst sites in South Africa's underground mines and documented the events in thousands of photographs, some of which have been compiled and published in a book. Over the past 30 years, great attention has been paid to rockbursts in other regions too, such as Canada and China, where mining and rock excavation are widely undertaken at great depth. A comprehensive five-year research program on rockburst in hard rock mines was carried out in the 1990s in Canada.
4
 The program includes mechanics of rockburst, rockburst support handbook, mine seismicity and numerical modelling. In the past decade, numerous rockburst events have been reported in excavations of road, railway, and headrace tunnels in China (e.g., Shan and Yan,

).
Rockbursts are classified into two categories — strain burst and fault-slip rockburst — in accordance with the major contributors of kinetic energy in the burst events. In a strain burst event, the kinetic energy for the burst is mainly converted from strain energy released from the rock mass. A strain burst may be triggered by the elevated tangential stress immediately following the excavation, thus being called a self-initiated strain burst,
9
 or by a fault-slip seismicity event, which is thus called a fault-slip triggered strain burst in this paper. In some cases, the fault-slip seismicity is so powerful that it contributes the major portion of the burst energy in a burst event. Such a burst is called fault-slip triggered rockburst in this paper. The difference between the fault-slip triggered strain burst and the fault-slip triggered rockburst is that the fault-slip seismicity only triggers the burst event in the former, whiles it both triggers and contribute the major portion of the burst energy in the latter. Numerous studies have been carried out in the physical simulation of strain burst in the laboratory (e.g. He et al.,
10

11
) and also in the theory of energy conversion during strain bursting.

 A substantial understanding of strain burst behavior has been gained through those studies as well as field observations, however, there are still outstanding issues that need to be clarified in the mechanics of strain burst. Two such issues are where the kinetic energy of a strain burst comes from and how the energy contribution from the surrounding rock mass varies with increasing burst depth. Limited studies have been carried out on these topics, such as by Kaiser,
20
 however, more comprehensive studies are required to gain insights into the detailed mechanics of strain bursting.
The study presented in this paper focuses on the energy sources in a strain burst event and the energy conversion during bursting, with an emphasis on the role of the surrounding rock mass. In this research, the characteristics of a strain burst event are first presented based on field observations. Two conceptual models are then proposed to illustrate the energy sources and conversions involved in a rockburst event. A hypothesis is proposed that the magnitude of a strain burst is increasingly associated with the energy released from the surrounding rock mass with increasing burst depth and volume. This hypothesis is verified both numerically and analytically in the paper.

Strain burst
Stress concentration is a prerequisite for strain burst. The tangential stress is elevated in the contour rock after excavation (Fig. 1
a); the rock then fails when the tangential stress exceeds the strength of the rock. The elastic strain energy stored in the failed rock and a certain amount of strain energy released from the surrounding rock mass, called the total potential strain energy, are dissipated mainly by rock fracture and rock ejection during bursting.
12
 A negligible amount of the energy is conversed to heat and vibration. In hard rock, the rock fracture may not be able to dissipate the entire potential strain energy and a portion of it is transformed to kinetic energy to eject the rock, which lead to the occurrence of a strain burst event. In some cases, the tangential stresses in the rock are elevated to such high levels that strain bursts occur instantly after excavation or a short time thereafter (Fig. 1b). The former behavior is called instant strain burst and the latter delayed strain burst, based on the time of burst occurrence.
21–24
 From the point of view of the triggering mechanism, both types belong to the self-initiated strain burst class because they are triggered by the static stress concentration after excavation.
9

,

20
 In other cases, the static stress concentration in the rock is insufficient to induce rock failure, so the rock is still intact after excavation. The arrival of seismic waves generated by fault slippage could elevate the tangential stress to the level of the rock strength so that a burst event is triggered. In this scenario, the seismic waves could also contribute extra energy for rock fragmentation and ejection, in addition to elevating the tangential stress. This type of burst is referred to as fault-slip triggered strain burst in this paper (Fig. 1c). The magnitude of a fault-slip triggered strain burst may vary within a large range depending on the amount of energy contributed by the seismic waves. Therefore, the magnitude of a fault-slip triggered strain burst may be similar to that of a self-initiated strain burst when the event is triggered by weak seismic waves (e.g. caused by a distant fault slippage), however, it could be much stronger if strong seismic waves (e.g. caused by a powerful fault slippage nearby) contribute a considerable amount of energy to the burst rock. Hereby burst rock refers to the rock that is ejected after bursting, while the surrounding rock is the rock immediately beside the ejected rock. The burst rock falls after busting, whiles the surrounding rock remains where it is but displaces somewhat.
A characteristic of both self-initiated and fault-slip triggered strain bursts is that the rock is intact before bursting. In a powerful self-initiated strain burst event, the rock is usually fractured into thin, knife-sharp slices, as shown in Fig. 2

In a fault-slip triggered strain burst event, the rock debris may be finely fragmented, as shown in Fig. 2b, which shows a rock pile after a strong fault-slip triggered strain burst event in a crosscut of an iron ore mine at a depth of approximately 1100 m. The fine fragmentation of the rock might result from a large amount of energy input from the seismicity in addition to the elastic strain energy released from the rock. In terms of their positioning, strain bursts often occur in the roof of mine drifts but may also occur on the excavation face and walls.

Conclusions
Two conceptual models were proposed to examine in detail the energy sources and their conversions involved in rockburst events. The prerequisite for a rockburst is that there must be excess kinetic energy after rock failure. The total kinetic energy W

k
 in a rockburst event is generally composed of three portions: one converted from the strain energy stored in the burst rock (W

bk
), one from the strain energy released from the surrounding rock mass (W

mk
), and one from the seismic energy (W

sk
). For a self-initiated strain burst, the kinetic energy is only composed of the W

bk
 and W

mk
 terms. The portion of the kinetic energy from the burst rock, W

bk
, i.e. the intrinsic burst energy, is a constant per unit volume for a given lithology, but the portion from the surrounding rock mass, W

mk
, increases with burst volume and depth. The magnitude of a shallow strain burst is mainly determined by the intrinsic burst energy of the burst rock itself, whereas, the strain energy released from the surrounding rock mass plays a more important role in rock ejection when the burst involves a large volume of rock. The relative role of the strain energy released from the surrounding rock mass was verified numerically and analytically in this study.
The key significance of the study is that it proves that the magnitude of a shallow strain burst is mainly determined by the intrinsic burst energy of the burst rock, whereas, the kinetic energy of a powerful deep and large-scale strain burst is mainly contributed by the surrounding rock mass. The proportion of the kinetic energy from the surrounding rock mass increases nonlinearly with the burst volume and depth. The implication of this study for engineering applications is that the attention of rockburst support design should be paid to the strain energy stored in the potential burst rock when it is estimated that light strain bursts are to occur, whereas the support design must take into account the contribution of the energy released from the surrounding rock mass.

1
Introduction
Coalbeds are often recognised as energy resources and storage reservoirs for geological sequestration of greenhouse gases, such as, carbon dioxide (CO2). Due to its extensive volume, the global coal deposits have significant potential to reduce the emission of CO2 into the atmosphere.
1
 Over the years, a number of field demonstration projects have been conducted across the world to store CO2 in coal seams.
2

,

3
 The pilot trials regularly reported the swelling-induced loss of gas injectivity and struggled to achieve a sustained rate of gas injection into the seams.
4–7
 CO2 adsorption in coal results in swelling of the coal matrix and reduce the permeability at the vicinity of the injection well.
8

,

9
 This leaves the bulk of the coal seam unused and questions the feasibility and practicality of the technologies pertinent to carbon sequestration in coal. Therefore, to address the gas injection and storage issues, comprehensive understanding of coal swelling and permeability behaviours are of paramount importance.
Coalbeds are naturally fractured sedimentary rocks, and are generally characterised by i) a well-defined and nearly uniform distributed network of natural fractures, known as cleats, and ii) by multiscale porous blocks that reside between the fractures, known as coal matrix.
10
 Coal contains two distinct types of cleats, e.g., face cleat and butt cleat. The face cleats are well-developed, widely spaced, nearly parallel fissures that run continuously throughout a coal seam. Butt cleats are perpendicular to the face cleats and poorly-developed fractures of limited length, and often terminate at the face cleats. Both type of cleats are nominally vertical, and perpendicular to the bedding planes.
11

,

12
 Cleat system provides the primary conduits for fluid flow in coalbeds,
12
 and the permeability of coal is predominantly dependent on the properties of the cleat networks. The distribution of cleats in coalbeds leads to anisotropic permeability where the greatest permeability occurs in the direction of the face cleats. This has been observed in both field observations and laboratory measurements and, therefore, questions the notion of isotropic material behaviour that is often considered in theoretical and numerical modelling studies. For example, Koenig and Stubbs
13
 reported that from the field tests in the Rock Creek coalbeds of the Warrior Basin in the USA, the permeability of coal in the direction parallel to the bedding plane is 17 times higher than that of the direction vertical to the bedding plane. Massarotto et al.
14
 investigated the permeability anisotropy of coals using a unique true tri-axial test in laboratory coal samples, and they reported that the permeability of coal was significantly directional. Another important, anisotropic property of coal is the directional swelling. Many laboratory experiments have confirmed the anisotropy of coal swelling. Day et al.
15
 measured the CO2 adsorption-induced swelling of three Australian bituminous coals at pressures up to 15 MPa with an optical method, and observed that the swelling in the plane perpendicular to the bedding plane was always significantly higher than that of the parallel plane. Similar results have been reported by Pan and Connell
16
 and Liu et al.
17
 The consequence of adsorption-induced coal deformations is that the in-situ stress field becomes disturbed,
7
 and it can further change the permeability behaviour. Therefore, accurate representation of the anisotropic coal swelling together with anisotropic permeability is essential.
Permeability change in coal is generally attributed to the net impacts of both effective stress and adsorption/desorption induced swelling/shrinkage stress or strains.
9
 Based on this concept, many permeability models have been developed to study the permeability behaviour of coals. A comprehensive review of these models is available in Liu et al.
18
 and Pan and Connell.
9
 Majority of these models assumed isotropy of coal properties and swelling behaviour. The permeability evolution is generally linked to the change in coal porosity using a cubic relationship between permeability, porosity, and different stress–strain relationships. Undoubtedly, these previous studies have enriched our understanding of coal permeability evolution, nevertheless, the anisotropy of the material and its behaviour have been often neglected. Gu and Chalaturnyk
19
 suggested that the change of permeability is anisotropic (due to the difference between butt cleats and face cleats) even though the initial permeability is assumed to be isotropic. The results presented by Liu et al.
20
 indicated that the application of isotropic deformation in permeability model could overestimate the permeability loss compared to the anisotropic deformation. Thus, anisotropic deformation should be considered to predict the coal permeability behaviour.
In recent years, a few anisotropic permeability models have been proposed to study the directional permeability behaviour of coal. Wang et al.
21
 developed an anisotropic permeability model by incorporating anisotropy of structural and mechanical deformation. Liu et al.
22
 derived a cleat aperture-dependent anisotropic permeability model, in which, a modulus reduction ratio is used to link the anisotropic deformation to the evolution of directional permeabilities. Pan and Connell
16
 presented an anisotropic permeability model by extending the swelling model of Pan and Connell.
23
 Like most of the isotropic permeability models, the aforementioned models assumed that the impacts of effective stress and shrinkage/swelling on coal permeability are independent. Pure stress or strain superposition was used to obtain the total changes in stress or strain, which was resulted from the pressure change and the shrinkage/swelling of the coal matrix. Actually, changes of strain or stress caused by pressure and shrinkage/swelling of coal are inter-related, especially under in situ conditions.
24
 The coupled anisotropic permeability model developed by Gu and Chalaturnyk
19
 shows some advantages in the analysis of anisotropic permeability, which considers discontinuous coal mass (containing cleats and matrix) to be an equivalent elastic continuum taking into account the cleat structure and characteristics of cleat deformation. However, the aperture changes in different directions are still quantified with the principle of strain superposition. The deformation of cleat aperture is closely related to cleat compressibility.
25
 Recent studies show that coal-gas interaction can alter the cleat compressibility,
26
 this important coupled effect has been ignored in the previous permeability models.
The purpose of this work is to present a comprehensive model that accounts for both anisotropic swelling and permeability behaviour in a practical and rigorous manner. Adsorption of gases on pores of coal matrices can alter the surfaces stress, influencing its effective stress. Firstly, an effective stress model for an anisotropic fractured porous media with dual porosity is derived using the surface stress approach. It is then used to describe anisotropic macroscopic coal swelling with anisotropic mechanical properties. Compared to the exiting anisotropic swelling model, the number of required parameters is reduced in the proposed model. An anisotropic, stress-dependent coal permeability model is then derived, in which directional fracture compressibilities are introduced. Stress or strain superposition is avoided compered to existing permeability models. More importantly, the impact of coal-gas interaction on cleat compressibility is considered in the proposed model. These new features of model could advance the understandings of coal permeability evolution. The accuracy and reliability of the developed models are examined by comparing the model results with relevant experimental data. Finally, the impacts of anisotropic swelling on coal permeability are investigated for different boundary conditions. The model can be used to study the mechanisms that control deformation and anisotropic permeability evolutions of coal, which are important for better predictions and analysis of subsurface carbon sequestration and coalbed methane recovery techniques.

5
Conclusions
In this study, an adsorption-induced anisotropic coal swelling and permeability model is presented. The model is developed by combining gas adsorption thermodynamics with anisotropic material properties. A stress-dependent directional permeability model is proposed to represent the anisotropy of coal permeability, in which a direction-related fracture compressibility factor is incorporated. A weakening coefficient is introduced to estimate the impact of gas adsorption on fracture compressibility. The accuracy and reliability of the proposed model are examined via a series of validation exercises against laboratory coal swelling and permeability data along with comparisons between presented and existing models. In all cases, the model predictions exhibit good agreement with the experimental data. The major findings are summarized as follows:

(1)
Gas adsorption induced coal swelling in the direction perpendicular to the bedding plane is greater than that in the parallel plane. Fracture compressibility may increase due to coal-gas interaction and CO2 can cause a larger increase in fracture compressibility compared to CH4 and N2.


(2)
Although coal permeability in any direction can be influenced by the stress changes in all directions, permeability parallel to the bedding plane is more sensitive to stress changes than that of the perpendicular to the bedding plane, especially change in stress perpendicular to the bedding plane.


(3)
Under constant volume condition, coal permeability drops significantly and no rebound was observed, however, coal permeability may rebound with pressure increase under uniaxial strain condition and plane strain condition. Anisotropic swelling and mechanical properties of coal can affect coal permeability anisotropy.


(4)
The decrease of coal permeability in direction parallel bedding plane is more significant than that in the direction perpendicular to the bedding plane.

Introduction
Chalk is characterised by soft plastic and brittle properties and the exploitation of chalk reservoirs results in wellbore instability, reservoir and overburden deformation, and seafloor subsidence.

 The field-scale deformations have important economic and societal impacts leading to, for instance, the temporary cessation and the drastic reduction of hydrocarbon production in the Tyra field for platform rebuild and in the Groningen field for safety reasons, respectively. Geomechanical models for chalk reservoirs were developed during the last three decades in order to predict rock deformation along wells and at the field scale so that suitable field development plans can be implemented to minimize risks.

 Knowledge acquired from tests on Maastrichtian chalk may therefore not be directly transferable to Danian rock. Experimental studies focused specifically on Danian chalk are necessary to study its mechanical properties and, ultimately, quantify its contribution to total reservoir compaction. A key question to address here is whether or not the constitutive relations established for Maastrichtian chalk can be used for Danian chalk.
In this context, our study aims at assessing the mechanical behaviour of Danian chalk with various amount of quartz in its rock fabric thanks to an extensive experimental dataset from the Joint Chalk Research library (JCR). Using hydrostatic compaction, shear failure, and unconfined compressive strength tests on oil-saturated specimens, the yield stresses, i.e., the stress at which plastic deformation is initiated, and the Mohr-Coulomb criteria (friction angle φ and rock cohesion 

C

) are quantified across a 30–45% porosity range. A comparison between the mechanical properties of Danian chalk reported in the present study and those previously documented on Maastrichtian rock is carried out and the factors controlling the observed differences are discussed.


2
Background knowledge
Contrary to the Maastrichtian chalk, the deposits from the Ekofisk Fm. in the Danish North Sea contain a non-negligible insoluble residue content, especially towards the base of the formation.
30
 The clay assemblage consists of smectite, illite, kaolinite and chlorite. Whereas chlorite is a product of diagenesis, and smectite and illite are likely detrital in origin, petrographic analysis shows that kaolinite can be both diagenetic and detrital in origin.
29,31,35
 On the other hand, quartz mainly consists of spheres ca. 50 nm in diameter that form larger aggregates of micro-quartz present in pore space.
29
 The micro-quartz formed during diagenesis by the dissolution and precipitation of siliceous organisms that were deposited on the seafloor together with calcareous organisms such as coccolithophores. Thus, the quartz/calcite ratio can in theory reflect variations in the proportion of siliceous and calcareous organisms deposited on the seafloor, while the amount of clay that is both diagenetic and depositional in origin, should record a rather ambiguous signal. The mineralogical analyses of chalk from two Danish North Sea reservoirs (Kraka and South Arne fields) showing a linear relationship between calcite and quartz content, and a data scattering when plotting calcite vs clay content support this hypothesis.
28
 Furthermore, Fig. 1
a shows the correlation between the amount of quartz and calcite for Danian chalk samples with a low clay content (below 4%) and collected within various North Sea fields. The clay-free chalk from the Ekofisk Fm. displays a clear linear correlation suggesting that the measured amount of quartz in the clay-free lithology is directly proportional to the ratio between the amount of siliceous vs calcareous organisms accumulated on the seafloor during time of deposition. Besides, micro-quartz reduces porosity by precipitating in pores and this porosity deterioration is observed in Fig. 1b. The porosity decline of clay-free chalk comes along with an increase in quartz content. This latter trend is associated with a scattering of the datapoints caused primarily by the change in the degree of calcite cementation between two clay-free Danian chalk samples with a similar quartz content.
28
 To conclude, the decline in the porosity of clay-free chalk from the Ekofisk Fm. appears inherently linked to a progressive rise in quartz content.

3.1
Materials and test procedures
A total of 20 triaxial tests carried out on Danian chalk are reviewed in the present study. This database was collected and archived by the JCR group (http://jointchalkresearch.org/) between 1971 and 2005 with most of the tests carried out after 1991 (Table 1
). Performed at room temperature, the experiments assessed the yield stresses and shear properties of reservoir chalk specimens with a porosity ranging between 30% and 45%. The visual inspection of the specimens indicate that the core material is representative of flawless pelagic sediments. Test results collected on specimens with defects (stylolites, fractures, extraclasts, intraclasts) were rejected during the data screening process. The mineralogical composition is estimated by X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 2
). The tested samples are mainly composed of calcite and quartz with a minor clay content below 4% except for the specimen labelled 336 that contains 15.7% clay (Table 1). The tested specimens are classified in two categories, clean (<3% quartz content) and impure (>4% quartz content) chalk (Fig. 2). Importantly, the quartz content of the impure lithology declines progressively with increasing porosity and above 40% porosity, its quartz content does not exceed 4% as observed in Danish North Sea fields (Fig. 1b). Besides, the selected core samples belong to four hydrocarbon reservoirs from the Danish and Norwegian sector of the North Sea, the Dan, South Arne, Ekofisk and Tor fields. 5
Discussion

5.1
Recrystallisation and cementation
The assessment of the plastic and shear properties of subsurface chalk indicates a mechanical contrast between clean specimens from the Ekofisk and Tor formations. Danian chalk appears stronger than the Maastrichtian counterparts during hydrostatic tests and this difference increases slightly as porosity declines (Fig. 6a). The rock lithification and the resulting strengthening of the rock fabric of clean chalk that can explain this contrast consists of two diagenetic processes, calcite recrystallisation and cementation.
36
 The recrystallisation involves a local redistribution of calcite during burial from less stable surfaces such as grain-to-grain contacts to more stable adjacent surfaces resulting in the formation of contact cement that strengthens the pore walls.
37
 The result of recrystallisation is smoother calcite grains and, thus, measurements of the specific surface that represents the area of the particle-pore interface in a given volume of rock were used as a proxy to assess the degree of recrystallisation between samples with a similar porosity.
35

,

38

,

39
 These studies systematically show a higher specific surface values in the Danian specimens than in the Maastrichtian specimens. According to this observation, chalk from the Ekofisk Fm. should have undergone a less pronounced recrystallisation of its rock fabric and thus, should display the softest mechanical properties, thereby contradicting the present results. Nevertheless, the laboratory data on the specific surface were collected on impure Danian chalk (<90% of calcite) and on clean Maastrichtian specimens (>94% calcite). Knowing that the quartz and clay minerals (5–60 m2/g) have a higher specific surface than calcite (0.5–3.5 m2/g),
40
 the reported difference in the particle-pore surface areas between both chalks is influenced by the mineralogical contrast between the studied specimens. Therefore, there is a lack of direct observations demonstrating a contrast in the degree of recrystallisation between clean chalk from the Ekofisk and Tor Fms at a given porosity in the North Sea. The cementation is another chemical process that can strengthen the rock fabric by precipitation of calcite cement in pores and around pre-existing grains. Exhaustive image analysis studies of >100 thin-sections of reservoir samples from the North Sea (Ekofisk, Valhall, South Arne, Dan and Tyra fields) have demonstrated that rocks from the Ekofisk Fm. display a higher amount of large grains (>316 μm2) than its counterpart from the Tor Fm.
41

,

42
 These large grains are microfossils containing intraparticle porosity that are partially to fully cemented by calcite. This additional amount of calcite cement within Danian chalk can explain its stronger mechanical behaviour under hydrostatic loading.

The specimens collected from the impure chalk lithology display a quartz content up to 24.5% at 35% porosity (Fig. 4b). Contrary, the quartz content of clean Danian specimens does not exceed 2.6%. More importantly, the difference in the mineralogical composition becomes significant below 38–40% porosity, which corresponds to the porosity threshold below which the porosity-trend of the yield stress of clean and impure chalk diverges. In the rock matrix, the quartz consists of μm-sized aggregates of nano-spheres mainly located in intergranular and intercrystalline porosity. These aggregates form during early burial by the dissolution, and later precipitation, of siliceous skeletons of radiolarians, diatoms, and sponges.

The plastic and shear properties of clean Maastrichtian and impure Danian chalk are also compared (Figs. 6b and 7). Despite the different porosity range investigated for the yield stress (32%–44%) and Mohr-Coulomb criteria (30%–45%), a consistent trend is observed in their mechanical responses during hydrostatic compaction and shear failure tests.  The outcomes of this work can thus assist engineers and geologists in developing simulators that capture the specific mechanical behaviour of Danian rocks and improve prediction on the contribution of the Ekofisk Fm. to the total strain occurring in oil and gas fields from the North Sea.
Besides, as part of the green energy transition, the economic viability of thermal energy and CO2 storage in onshore and offshore Denmark has been confirmed by feasibility studies.
48–51
 These sectors of industry involve periodic injection/production of fluids with various chemical composition and temperature in subsurface chalk of Maastrichtian and Danian age. The geomechanical alteration of chalk is expected to occur due to calcite and quartz dissolution by acidified carbonate water and by Mg-bearing fluids at high temperature (>90 °C).
52

,

53
 Thus, among others, the quartz content plays a role in the alteration of chalk properties by controlling the fluid-calcite surface area available for chemo-mechanical interactions and by promoting rock compaction at high temperature. In the present study, the differences in the mechanical behaviour between Danian and Maastrichtian chalk with a high and low quartz content, respectively, are of significance changing the shear and plastic properties by a factor of 20%–60%. Further quantitative studies on the influence of quartz content on the geomechanical properties of chalk are thus required to provide a solid knowledge base, from which experimental and simulation studies can be carried out on the short- and long-term effects of CO2 and thermal energy storage on reservoir integrity.



6
Conclusion
This study aims at quantitatively assessing and interpreting the contrast in the plastic and shear behaviour of reservoir chalk deposited in the Ekofisk and Tor Fms from the North Sea. To this purpose, a total of 20 triaxial tests, including hydrostatic compaction, shear failure and unconfined compression tests collected from the JCR database and carried out at room temperature on oil-saturated Danian chalk are investigated and compared with published data on Maastrichtian chalk. The studied specimens span from 30% to 45% porosity to cover the full spectrum of Danian chalk that is likely to deform plastically in a depleted field.
The main outcome of this study is that the constitutive relations established for Maastrichtian chalk and based on experimental studies cannot be used for Danian chalk. Firstly, the data obtained on the stress values at pore collapse show a systematic stronger mechanical behaviour of the clean and impure Danian chalk compared with the clean Maastrichtian counterparts for specimens with a porosity below 38–40%. Above this porosity threshold, the three chalk types tend to display similar stress conditions at the onset of plastic deformation. The strengthening of chalk from the Ekofisk Fm. below 38% porosity is more pronounced when specimens contain more than 4% quartz, thereby emphasizing the role of mineralogy on chalk geomechanics. Secondly, the friction angle and rock cohesion values are also higher for the Danian chalk containing >4% quartz than for the clean Maastrichtian specimens, especially towards low porosity below 38–40%. Porosity-dependent functions are extrapolated from these observed trends and proposed to estimate the hydrostatic yield stress and Mohr-Coulomb criteria of the impure and clean Danian chalk. Furthermore, the yield surface of chalk from the Ekofisk Fm. with a 30%–45% porosity range is reconstructed in a

-porosity graph and compared with that of the Maastrichtian chalk. This comparison indicates for instance that the yield surface and, thus, the mechanical properties of the impure Danian specimens with a 40% and 37.5% porosity are similar to that of Maastrichtian chalk with a 37.5% and 35% porosity, respectively. These differences in the shear and plastic behaviour are of significance during geomechanical simulation, modifying the onset and amount of deformation taking place in the Ekofisk and Tor Fms. of depleted reservoirs. The greater amount of quartz measured in the specimens from the Ekofisk Fm. is thought to primary control the observed mechanical contrast between Danian and Maastrichtian deposits. Cementation is also considered as a secondary parameter influencing this mechanical contrast.
Importantly, the impure Danian specimens studied here contain up to 56% quartz, a value that is higher than the average 5–20% quartz content commonly reported in Danian chalk from the North Sea. Recalling that quartz contributes to strengthen the rock matrix, this study likely reports the maximum difference in the shear and plastic properties between impure and clean chalk from the Ekofisk and Tor Fms, respectively. The outcomes of this work can be integrated in constitutive models and assist engineers and geologists in developing geomechanical simulators that capture the specific mechanical behaviour of Danian and Maastrichtian rocks in the context of hydrocarbon exploitation as well as CO2 and energy storage.

Introduction
Rock spalling is a type of stress-induced failure that occurs around deep excavation boundaries, in the absence of confining pressure. It often appears as rock splitting and flaky exfoliation in hard rocks, but can also manifest itself through shearing in weaker rocks.
1
 Fairhurst and Cook
2
 first described spalling failure as the development of extension fractures (Mode I) under compressive loading. A number of early field studies
3

,

4
 have concluded that the direction in which spalling failure propagates is generally along that of the minimum compressive stress, and the final breakout can have different shapes such as “dog ear” or “cusp”,
5
 as shown in Fig. 1.

Over the past few decades, spalling type failure leading to the development of V-shaped breakouts has been observed to occur at the centimetre scale in field studies involving deep underground experimental tunnels and boreholes, such as the Mine-by experiment tunnel run by the Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) Underground Research Laboratory
7
 and the Äspö Pillar Stability Experiment (APSE) conducted in the Hard Rock Laboratory (HRL) in Sweden.
8
 Several failure mechanisms have been proposed to explain the development of the spalled zone. Santarelli and Brown
9
 and Haimson and Song
10
 proposed that the failure mechanisms by which breakouts occur are different depending on the rock rheology. In hard rocks, spalling results from tensile fractures that initiate parallel to the borehole wall, while in weaker rocks it initiates at the borehole boundary and develops through shearing. Shen and Barton
11
 emphasise that spalling may be the starting point of a breakout, but tensile failure is restricted to the immediate vicinity of an underground free surface, where extensional strain regime exists. Spalling has also been observed to occur in drilling experiments on centimetre scale cores for different rock types, including granites, limestones, and sandstones.
12



1.1
Review of existing numerical models
Numerical methods for simulating rock fracturing can be divided into three main categories: continuum, discontinuum, and hybrid methods. Several spalling models have been implemented using continuum numerical methods and conventional plasticity theory. 
1
 Hajiabdolmajid et al.
13

,

14
 concluded that conventional constitutive laws such as elastic perfectly-plastic or elastic brittle–plastic cannot replicate the shape and depth of the spalled zone in strong rocks. The reason proposed for this is that in the conventional Mohr–Coulomb and Hoek–Brown criteria, the strength components (cohesion and friction angle) are assumed to be mobilised simultaneously. To overcome this limitation, Hajiabdolmajid et al.
13
 proposed modified versions of the Mohr–Coulomb and Hoek–Brown criteria, in which the cohesive and frictional strength components are functions of the accumulated plastic strain. Similarly, Diederichs
15
 used a cohesion-weakening frictional strengthening model with modified Hoek–Brown parameters to develop the Damage Initiation Spalling Limit (DISL) criterion.
Therefore, when implementing continuum approaches to model rock spalling, a modified constitutive criterion is usually required to capture the brittle rock response.
13–16
 While the cohesion weakening friction strengthening (CWFS) criterion used in continuum approaches generates results in agreement with the field observations, it requires an a priori estimation of the plastic strain limits at which the cohesion component reaches its residual value and the frictional component becomes fully mobilised. Martin
17
 also highlights that the existing numerical studies using continuum methods can only provide an approximation of the fracturing process, which is inherently discrete. Another set of methods suitable for modelling borehole failure are the discontinuum numerical methods. Cundall
18
 provided a detailed account of discrete element methods (DEM) and their implementations, alongside their applicability in modeling discrete fracture initiation and growth.
An advantage of the discrete element method is that it does not depend on the previously mentioned constitutive criteria to define the fracturing process. Instead, particle contact 
19
 is used to replicate brittle failure. The domain is discretised, each particle contact given a local, micro–strength and when the tensile or shear strength at the contact is overcome, it breaks. The progressive micro–failure process continues with subsequent bonds breaking, which then results in a stress redistribution around the domain and eventual macro–failure. A disadvantage of this method is that the given particle contact strengths, as well as particle shapes, sizes and clustering are not geomechanically informed, and so the accuracy of the fracture process cannot be verified.
Numerical studies using discontinuum methods showed that micro-scale heterogeneity 
20
, grain interlocking 
21
, and grain clustering 
22
 are important factors involved in tensile failure in hard, brittle rocks such as granites. Lan et al.
20
 introduced the effect of small scale heterogeneities in a grain-based model, using the discrete element method (DEM). Polygonal grains of variable sizes were bonded together through contacts that accounted for the micro heterogeneity, but also allowed simulation of intra-element fracturing. Using a heterogeneous approach, Lan et al.
23
 and Elmo and Stead
24
 reproduced the depth and shape of spalling around the APSE pillar, and pillar strength, emphasising the importance of both grain-scale and large-scale heterogeneity in modeling borehole spalling.
The suitability of using a combined finite/discrete element method (FDEM) in order to simulate brittle fracturing has been investigated in several studies.
25–29
 This method is based on modelling fracture and damage processes explicitly, in order to simulate the transition from a continuous to a discontinuous domain, and hence replicate the fracture initiation and propagation more accurately. Vlachopoulos and Vazaios 
25
 recently simulated spalling damage using a combined finite–discrete element method (FDEM) in their model, and compared their results with the continuum DISL approach. Using the FDEM method, they were capable of simulating fracture initiation, coalescence, and propagation in two dimensions, as progressively larger stresses were applied to the borehole. Whereas discrete and hybrid methods have been shown to predict the spalled zone accurately to some extent, fracture growth is restricted to occur only along pre-existing element boundaries, where contact strength is initially assigned. In contrast, when fractures grow in geological media, their development influences the stress field in the vicinity of the crack, thereby affecting the fracture growth trajectories and the final fracture patterns, which end up being different from the predicted path.
The present study differs from those described above, as it investigates spalling in three dimensions, and applies a first-principle geometric fracture growth approach to model spalling/failure patterns. Fractures are modelled as distinct and explicit entities, and the volumetric discretisation of the rock domain is updated at every growth step to accommodate the evolving fracture geometry. Section 2 provides a comprehensive description of the methodology used.


1.2
The nuclear waste context
Deep underground disposal is widely considered one of the safer options for long-term disposal of nuclear waste. This type of disposal is based on a “multiple barrier concept”,
30
 which introduces several protective layers between the disused fuel and the environment/society. There are several on-going projects, at different completion stages, which investigate the engineered (e.g. type of canister, composition of the buffer, shape of the borehole), and the natural barriers (e.g. suitability of different host rock types, such as evaporites, crystalline rocks, argillaceous rocks, etc.), to determine their long-term behaviour and optimal configurations for safe repository design.
The Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Company (SKB) has been undertaking site characterisation at Forsmark, where the Swedish deep geological repository for spent nuclear fuel is planned to be emplaced. The site is described extensively in SKB Technical Report SKB TR-08-05,
31
 which presents the integrated understanding of the bedrock geology, hydrogeology, rock mechanical and thermal properties, in situ stresses, and existing fracture domains and deformation zones.
The construction of a deep nuclear waste repository will involve excavating and drilling a range of underground structures of different geometries and sizes, such as access tunnels, deposition tunnels and deposition boreholes.
32
 One of the key issues that remains under investigation at Forsmark is the stability of the underground openings, and more specifically, the impact of stress-induced fractures on the deposition tunnels and boreholes, as well as their effect on the properties of the immediately-surrounding host rock. Understanding how over-stressed rock will behave following the creation of these voids will ensure an effective repository design and its long-term stability and maintenance.
Several telescopic boreholes drilled as part of the Forsmark site investigation work
33

,

34
 presented typical breakout patterns (Fig. 1), with widths and depths in the range of 40–180
°
 and 0.2–67.5 mm respectively. These boreholes were percussion drilled with a diameter of cca. 200–250 mm in the first 100 m, and core drilled with a diameter of cca. 77 mm in the following 1000 m. Their dimensions and excavation methods are different from those of the future deposition boreholes,
35
 which will accommodate the spent fuel, but the occurrence of spalling patterns in the investigation boreholes indicates possible stress-induced fracture growth impact on the deposition boreholes as well.
The main goals of this study are: (1) determine the effectiveness of the geometric fracture growth method in reproducing fracture mechanisms associated with mechanical spalling, and (2) model fracture initiation and growth following the excavation stage of underground openings in brittle rock formations. The Forsmark candidate area is chosen to investigate the impact of in situ stresses, deposition tunnel orientation, borehole geometry and spacing on the predicted breakout patterns. Since no deposition boreholes have yet been drilled at Forsmark, this paper also presents the first numerical predictions of fracture growth leading to spalling at the planned repository site.



2
Methodology
The present work models stress-induced spalling fractures geometrically, in an isotropic, homogeneous, and linear elastic brittle rock domain. Fractures are represented discretely using smooth parametric surfaces and their growth is evaluated at each fracture tip, where three modal stress intensity factors (SIFs) are calculated, capturing both tension and shear. SIFs represent the energy necessary to deform the fracture, and they determine the extent and orientation of growth vectors at every fracture tip.
The volumetric discretisation of the domain conforms to the evolving fracture geometry and is updated at each growth step to follow the new internal geometry. Fracture extension is thus not constrained by the mesh. Multiple fractures of different sizes and evolving shapes grow in response to the local stress state at their tips, with growth being influenced by the stress distribution within the domain, accounting for in situ stresses, fracture interaction, and variations in material properties due to ensuing damage.
This method has been applied in three dimensions in other studies, including fracture interaction,
36
 hydraulic fracturing,
37

,

38
 and THM fracture growth in the context of geothermal energy.
39
 In particular, the present work presents extensions to the method that describe the nucleation of new fractures and the pervasive use of lofting to update geometric descriptions of fractures during growth. During the simulation, fracture geometry is always stored independently from the mesh,
40
 and a new optimised mesh is created at every iteration at minimal computational cost using a fully parallel octree-based volumetric algorithm. The finite element method is used to compute the deformation in the system, taking into account the physical properties of both the rock domain and the fracture surfaces.

2.3.2
Number of initial disks
The number of initial seeds is the maximum number of fractures that can nucleate during a simulation. When the damage criterion is not satisfied, additional fractures will not nucleate, regardless of whether the maximum number of fractures has been reached or not. Fig. 2 shows an example of nucleating 100 initial fracture disks, with the different sizing strategies explained above. The present approach does not aim to numerically model growth of every individual fracture that occurs at the borehole wall. Instead, flaws are geometrically modelled in locations where the damage is the highest.

The initial fracture disks are prevented from nucleating on the surface of the borehole wall, but there is no artificial restriction on growth, as the fractures are allowed to evolve following fracture mechanics principles (see Section 2.4). The nucleation process is in line with the earliest two stages of spalling observed by Haimson

The nucleation method used in this paper captures the sequential nature of the breakout development partially. There are no micro-fractures forming at the borehole wall that coalesce and buckle in a progressive manner. Instead, a damage model is used to determine the loci of fracture initiation. The final shapes and depths of failure are suitably reproduced (Section 4), after growth and interaction of the macro-fractures is completed. Since fracture growth is determined by the energy at the fracture tip, each nucleated fracture disk will extend to accommodate the damage around it until it either intersects a free surface, or ends up in the stress shadow zone of another fracture, which had already accounted for the damage present in its respective neighbourhood.

The fracture geometry consists of an ensemble of points, curves and surfaces, and it evolves as a function of deformation. Fractures are represented through non-uniform B-splines (NURBS) curves and surfaces. NURBS have been increasingly used in representing fracture domains,

 because they can accurately describe a wide range of shapes: from simple 2D lines and curves, to more complex 3D free-form surfaces and volumes. Piegl and Tiller
62
 give a general overview of NURBS and Paluszny et al.
63
 show the advantages of using NURBS in the context of fracture mechanics with explicit geometric representation of fracture shapes.

Fig. 3A shows an example of fracture growth under uniaxial tension from an initial smooth disk, for a total of five growth steps. In this case, the fracture surface is constructed by connecting the old (prior to growth) and new (after growth) sets of fracture tips through triangles.

During the first growth step, the initial smooth crack boundary becomes a set of polylines, connected at the fracture tips. This process causes a high density mesh (Fig. 3C) to be generated around the fracture, to conform with the evolving fracture geometry. An improved construction of the geometry of the fracture surface is through lofting (Fig. 3B), which results in a coarser mesh of high quality that provides a smooth representation of the geometry, while maintaining fidelity to the fracture geometry.

The geometric process of lofting consists of performing curve interpolations across the control points of the section curves, resulting in the control net of the surface. Control points do not necessarily always lie on the physical location of those of the curves, but rather describe their domain through a series of recursive operations that translate a local reference space into a curve or surface that exists in physical space.
The newly constructed surface is called a lofted surface, as it lofts or approximates the region between a pair of two curves, each described by a set of control points of equal size. These cross-sectional curves become isoparametric curves of the lofted surface as shown in Fig. 4. The final surface shape will depend on the number, shape and positioning of the section curves, and will evolve as in the natural system by adding new surfaces to the existing surface object. Piegl and Tiller
62
 provide an in-depth description of NURBS geometries and relevant operations.

In the context of modelling fracture growth in nuclear waste repositories, NURBS representations of fractures are advantageous for several reasons: they capture details at many scales, since they are not limited by a specific resolution; they do not require large storage memory, which would be problematic if hundreds of fractures are generated; they are consistent with emerging isogeometric methods. The gains from representing complex geometries using parametric surfaces, such as NURBS, are substantial, allowing for substantially higher quality meshes to be generated in an efficient manner for their use in both mechanics and flow numerical experiments.

The Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) carried out the Mine-by tunnel experiment

The maximum depth of the spalled zone was approximately 50 cm, with variations along the tunnel length, and the rock mass remained intact beyond this point.

Fig. 6B and C show the final fractured zone geometry, after the spalling process has stabilised and fracture growth has arrested, in radial and axial view respectively. Each macro-fracture that interacts with the borehole wall can be regarded as a “fractured zone”. When compared with other numerical studies, which model the progressive splitting of the borehole wall through coalescence of smaller fractures,

Spalling extent is given by the fractured region around the borehole. For each fracture surface, the “spalling depth” is the maximum distance measured between fracture tip nodes and the borehole wall, and the “spalling width” is the maximum arc length of that fracture around the borehole, as seen from an observation point at the top of the borehole. The maximum measured depths and widths of the two fracture arrays forming the diametrically-opposite notches (Fig. 6B) are consistent with those observed in the field (Fig. 6A). Although a relatively small number of fracture disks are initiated, i.e., 10, they are allowed to grow freely, based on the energy in the system, eventually covering the entire length of the borehole and accommodating the whole range of damage that develops in the near-borehole region after the borehole drilling stage.
Rock buckling and collapse into the borehole are not explicitly modelled, but the loss of integrity of the borehole is accounted for through damage. This is illustrated in Fig. 7, where the elastic modulus of the host rock is degraded (Eq. (7)) in the vicinity of the borehole, amounting to a 60% reduction in the intact rock elastic modulus (Fig. 7A). Once fractures nucleate, Young’s Modulus is reduced completely in the elements neighbouring the newly spawned fracture surfaces (Fig. 7B). Further degradation of the rock mass occurs as fractures grow (Fig. 7C), covering the whole length of the tunnel. As opposed to the field experiment where the two diametrically opposite spalled zones were asymmetrical, the fractured zones in the numerical model tend to be symmetrical, due to the prescribed homogeneity and isotropy of the numerical domain.

5
Effect of the deposition tunnel
The deposition tunnel is expected to affect fracture nucleation and growth patterns, through changing the stress state at the top of the deposition boreholes, where it acts as a free surface. Saceanu et al.
67
 showed that the same tunnel effect can be modelled in two ways: (a) by explicitly modelling the deposition tunnel as an individual body in a larger domain, or (b) using modified boundary conditions on the top surface of the domain and creating a “free” boundary where the deposition borehole is attached. This change has a minimal effect on the simulated fracture geometries, but is computationally more efficient, since it employs a simplified domain, with a reduced number of nodes and elements. The resulting stress fields around the borehole were shown to be nearly identical in the two models where either the whole tunnel, or the tunnel floor, was simulated.
67



Fig. 8 shows the damage (Eq. (8)) distribution in a full borehole and tunnel model, following the nucleation of the initial fracture disks. The tunnel is excavated in one step and the displacements, strains and stresses are computed in the model containing only the tunnel. Subsequently, the borehole is drilled in one step, and the stresses are re-computed in the full borehole and tunnel model. Fig. 8 A–C shows separate instances of preferred nucleation loci in the full model containing 10, 50 and 100 initial disks respectively. The highest damage concentrations occur at the intersection of the tunnel floor and its sidewalls and at the intersection of the deposition borehole wall and the wedge-shaped access ramp. These results are in line with experimental observations where fractures nucleate preferentially around sharp-edged boundaries.
74


Numerically, first fractures to nucleate are those at the edges of the tunnel floor (Fig. 8A), followed by spalling of the borehole top/access ramp (Fig. 8B), and finally spalling of the lower curvature surfaces such as the tunnel roof and the rest of the borehole wall (Fig. 8C). This is also an example of the complexity of a full borehole and tunnel model, which requires hundreds of fractures to capture the complete state of the damage present around both cavities. In this paper, only the fractures directly involved in the development of the borehole breakouts/borehole spalling are further analysed. Consequently, the single-step borehole excavation is considered to be representative of the subsurface behaviour, given that observed fractures take significantly longer time (4–8 months
7
) to develop the v-shaped notches in the field, compared to 30–105 h

Effect of the borehole geometry
This section investigates the effect of borehole geometry on the predicted spalling around a typical deposition borehole. The cylindrical borehole is modified at the junction with the tunnel floor to provide an access ramp for the spent fuel canisters. This is a potentially practical modification that could provide additional space to operate the machines that will lower the spent fuel canisters into the borehole, effectively reducing the requirement of a ‘tall’ deposition tunnel.
68
 Three cases were investigated, where the borehole top is cylindrical, conical, and wedge-shaped (Fig. 5D).

Numerical results show that spalling occurs in all cases, and the modified geometries affect fracture nucleation and growth patterns (Fig. 12). Fractures nucleate uniformly on either side of the circular borehole (Fig. 12A), but concentrate at the borehole top in the other two simulated cases (Fig. 12B, C). The enlargement of the borehole top induces higher stress concentrations at the borehole–tunnel junction, increasing the depth of failure in the top metre of the borehole. Fracture growth is quantified in terms of maximum spalling depths and total fractured surface areas, showing increasing severity from circular, to cone to wedge (Table 2). Although the maximum absolute spalling depth is the largest in the wedge-shaped borehole case, this only occurs when the tunnel floor is orientated perpendicular to the maximum compressive stress direction. The fractured areas responsible for increased spalling depth on the ramp side are, as shown in Fig. 12C, involved in the spalling of the ramp itself. However, if the tunnel is orientated parallel to the direction of the maximum compressive stress, the stress conditions required for ramp spalling would not be fulfilled and fractures would nucleate 90
°
 away from the ramp, and grow as in the case of a simple circular borehole. For this reason, the symmetrical cone top is not recommended, as it would increase failure severity in all stress and/or tunnel orientation scenarios.

9
Conclusions
Geometric fracture growth simulations, based on the finite element method, are used to investigate stress-induced fracturing processes leading to spalling around deposition boreholes under different underground conditions. Several scenarios are considered, in which the in situ stresses, borehole geometries and spacing are varied to assess the impact on final fracture patterns and damage extent.
In the case of a single circular borehole excavated in a homogeneous and isotropic rock domain, results indicate that spalling failure initiates in areas of high damage close to the borehole wall and continues to develop in the direction of the least compressive stress 


σ


3


, in agreement with experimental observations from laboratory and field studies.
When the deposition tunnel floor was incorporated as a free surface, fractures at the intersection between the borehole and the tunnel nucleated preferentially parallel to the tunnel floor, and perpendicular to the borehole wall. This results in larger apparent spalled zones widths, but lower fractured surface area. Fractures in that case grow more horizontally, in the direction of the tunnel floor, instead of vertically, along the borehole itself. They also show less interaction with the borehole wall in the borehole axial direction. The tunnel is then rotated at different angles to the maximum horizontal stress, in order to assess the impact of stress orientation on fracture growth. Since the relative stress magnitudes were kept constant regardless of the tunnel orientation, the extent of the fractured zone remained consistent in all orientation cases, for a circular borehole.
Another scenario that was examined was the influence of varying in situ stress magnitudes. Results showed that damage exceeds the threshold required for nucleation in the near-borehole region, for the expected subsurface conditions at Forsmark. In the case of higher far-field stress differential, the fractures involved in spalling extended deeper into the host rock domain, while lower stress anisotropy caused the fracturing process to stabilise more locally.
Finally, the effect of neighbouring boreholes and inter-borehole distance was investigated. Numerical results determined that the maximum stress concentration around flanked boreholes does not change significantly, regardless of the total number of boreholes in the model, provided that the domain boundaries and number of initial disks are adjusted accordingly, and the inter-borehole distance remains constant. The three-, five- and seven-borehole models were fundamentally identical in terms of fracturing behaviour around flanked (inner) borehole(s), and flanking (outer) boreholes. On the other hand, inter-borehole spacing plays an important role in pillar stability. Under the given conditions at Forsmark, circular boreholes need to be spaced at least 4 m apart to maintain pillar integrity under mechanical loading. In the case where access ramps are drilled, the spacing should be increased to at least 6 m, so that stability of the top of the borehole is ensured.
The present approach to model spalling failure and general fracturing around boreholes provides useful and quick information for designing a safe repository for nuclear waste storage. The modelled fracture patterns are consistent with previous studies and field observations, and the computational cost to generate them is low. The extent of the fractured areas around boreholes depends on a number of repository design parameters, some of which can be adjusted to minimise spalling severity and eventually reduce the risk for leaking radionuclides in this highly fractured zone.
