Introduction
The similarity simulation experiment model is becoming increasingly popular in studying the physical and mechanical properties of rock samples.
1–3
 Three similarity simulation experimental methods are commonly used to study the characteristics of rock samples, in which: (1) mineral composition and proportion are completely similar to those of natural rock samples,
4
 (2) mineral composition and proportions are only partially similar to those of natural rock samples
5
 and (3) mineral composition and proportion are completely different from that of natural rock samples.
6
 Of the abovementioned three methods, experimental method 1 is most suitable for investigating the physical and mechanical properties of rock samples due to its ability to meet the challenges of natural rock research, such as high costs of sampling.
4–10


While most previous studies have focused mainly on the synthesis of similar hard rock and soil, research work on the synthesis of soft rock materials is limited because the decrease in mechanical properties of the soft rocks resulting from water–rock interaction makes the synthesis challenging. Red bed soft rocks, which are widely distributed in Southern China, could affect many infrastructure projects, such as high-rise buildings and subways.
11

,

12
 The physical, chemical and mechanical properties of the soft rocks change significantly when they contact water.
12–15
 Therefore, the synthesis of red mudstone–like materials becomes necessary for studying the physical and mechanical properties of red mudstone soft rocks.
Many previous studies on synthetic rock (soil) materials used cement as a cement agent. For example, sand, kaolinite and silica fume with cement were synthesised to study the mechanical properties of sandstone or mudstone.
6

,

16
 Consoli et al. synthesised cemented silty soil by mixing cement, water and soil for unconfined compressive testing with the aim of pavement base construction, channel lining and earth dam slope protection.
8
 Fedrizzi et al. studied the petrophysical properties of carbonate rocks by using cement to bond calcite and quartz instead of expensive natural cores.
4
 Arora et al. synthesised mudstone by mixing clay, cement and water, and compared the physical and mechanical properties with natural rock samples to address the challenges of obtaining natural, uniform and undisturbed samples.
5
 Mondol et al. synthesised mudstone-like materials by mixing water, kaolinite and montmorillonite and by using mechanical compression (different vertical stress) to study their physical properties.
7
 Nooraiepour et al. synthesised mudstone from water, quartz, kaolinite and montmorillonite by mechanical compression (different vertical stress) to study the permeability and physical properties of rocks.

According to previous research results, the study of rock-like materials generally only involves mechanical properties or physical properties; in the study of mechanical properties, cement is often used as a cement agent. Due to the brittleness of cement, the previous synthesis methods are mostly suitable for high-strength brittle, hard rock. For ductile and low-strength soft rock, such as red mudstone, it is difficult to obtain reasonable peak strength and post peak curve. In addition, cement changes the mineral composition of rock-like materials (which react to form tricalcium silicate, dicalcium silicate, tricalcium aluminate, tetracalcium aluminate and calcium hydroxide), making rock-like materials very different from natural rocks. Some studies used sodium silicate (Na2SiO3) as a cement agent to solve this problem (water and silica are produced after sodium silicate decomposition).

,

18


The diagenetic process of sedimentary rocks is generally the result of the joint action of cementation and compaction.

,

20
 In previous research, similarity simulation experiments were mostly conducted from one aspect of diagenesis, and the synthesis of rock-like materials in relation to more than one factor has not been studied. For this reason, rock-like materials are similar to natural rocks in only one aspect: physical or mechanical properties.
The main purpose of this study is to provide a method to accurately synthesise and replace natural red mudstone in a certain range. In this study, red mudstone–like materials were synthesised by the similarity simulation experiment method (1) to study the physical and mechanical properties of the rocks through diagenesis of sedimentary rocks. First, red mudstone–like materials were synthesised according to the effects of sodium silicate content (c

Third, the synthesis method was validated by comparing the properties of red mudstone–like materials and natural red mudstone, and the relationship between the physical and mechanical properties of red mudstone–like materials and synthesis parameters was established.


2
Materials and methods

2.1
Materials
In this study, red mudstone-like materials were synthesised by the method of completely similar mineral composition and proportion to natural rock samples. The mineral composition of mudstone mainly includes clay minerals, quartz, feldspar and fine mica. There are also some small components such as calcite. The chemical composition of mudstone is mainly SiO2 and Al2O3 and some other oxides such as K2O, MgO, and Na2O. Red mudstone also contains some hematite (Fe2O3), which is the main reason for its red color. The classification of most identified fine-grained rocks is based on the relative abundance of silt and clay grains in these rocks. The relative abundance of silt and clay grains in mudstone ranges from 25% to 50% and from 50% to 75%, respectively.
21
 The total mass of components needed to synthesise a mudstone sample is 500 g, as shown in Table 1
. Quartz particle size is less than 0.075 mm.
Sodium silicate was selected as the cement agent to bind various mineral components in the sample preparation. It is a kind of inorganic material, different from Portland cement, it has a certain ductility, and also has a certain solubility after meeting water, which is suitable for the synthesis of soft rock such as red mudstone.
18




2.2
Synthesis of red mudstone–like materials
Mineral components were weighed out as per the quantities in Table 1 and mixed thoroughly. To prepare the cement agent, mixtures comprising various percentages of sodium silicate in water were prepared (Table 2
). The samples and cement agent were then mixed thoroughly and placed into a cylindrical mold for mechanical compression (Fig. 1
a). The mold is composed of two semi cylinders, two circular sleeves and a base (Fig. 1b). After the mold is assembled (Fig. 1c), the mixture of mineral and cement agent can be loaded.
The mechanical compression times t and vertical stress σ

v
 applied to the samples are shown in Table 2. Samples were then ground flat at both ends and processed into cylindrical samples, each with a diameter of 50 mm and a height of 100 mm (Fig. 1d). The samples were put into a drying box and dried to a constant weight for subsequent tests.


2.3
Physical and mechanical tests
The physical tests included dry density ρ and wave velocity v (P-wave). Wave velocity v was detected by the C61 Non-Metallic Ultrasonic Detector in the Guangdong Key Infrastructure Safety Engineering Technology Research Center. C61 Non-Metallic Ultrasonic Detector can generate 5 Hz-500 kHz sound wave, and then use the sound wave transmission method to detect the properties of non-metallic materials such as rocks, and can record the dynamic waveform and wave velocity v in real time. Both ends of each sample were coated evenly with petroleum jelly, then two transducers were used to get close to both ends of the sample and collect the compressional wave velocity v. The microstructure of each sample was elucidated by the Zeiss EVO Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) in the Instrumental Analysis and Research Center, Sun Yat-sen University. Zeiss Evo Scanning Electron Microscope is an analytical microscope with the ability to process various materials. It can be used for the analysis and identification of particle morphology and chemical composition.
Mechanical tests were conducted using a high spatiotemporal resolution 3D visualisation test system for multifield coupling damage of rock in the Guangdong Key Infrastructure Safety Engineering Technology Research Center. The experimental system can be loaded with a maximum axial force of 1000 kN and a conventional confining pressure of 20 MPa. In the uniaxial compression tests, the sample is first placed on the equipment, and then the axial stress is applied in the strain control mode until the sample is destroyed. In the triaxial compression tests, firstly, the sample needs to be wrapped with rubber film and the sample is placed on the equipment, then the confining pressure is increased to the target value by using the stress control mode, and finally the axial stress is applied by using the strain control mode until the sample is damaged. The axial loading speed for the uniaxial test and triaxial test was 0.2 mm/min, and the confining pressure loading speed for the triaxial test was 0.1 MPa/min. The confining pressures for the triaxial compression test were 0, 1, 2 and 3 MPa, respectively. Each group of samples in uniaxial compression test should be tested for 3 times, and each group of samples in triaxial compression test should be tested for 4 times according to different confining pressure.

Results

3.1

Microstructure
The microstructure of the cracks in samples after uniaxial compression testing is shown in Fig. 3

3.4
Failure mode of red mudstone–like material

3.4.1
Failure mode in uniaxial compression tests

Fig. 8
 shows the failure mode of red mudstone–like material in the uniaxial compression test. The main failure mode of the red mudstone–like material with low sodium silicate content c

4
Discussion

4.1
Comparison of red mudstone–like materials with natural rocks
Red mudstone–like materials and natural rocks were compared in this study in terms of rock mineral composition, physical properties, and mechanical properties.
The sample used in this study was a red mudstone–like material. Its mineral composition was the same as that of natural red mudstone, and the synthesis process was a mechanical compression method that does not cause chemical changes in the sample. Moreover, the added cement agent will not change the mineral composition of red mudstone like materials. This proves that the red mudstone like material synthesised in this study is a kind of mudstone in terms of mineral composition.
By comparing physical property indicators (dry density ρ and wave velocity v) obtained in this study (Fig. 10
a and b), it can be seen that the dry density ρ and wave velocity v of the red mudstone–like materials are within the range of natural mudstone–related properties (Ref.-1).
22
 The dry density ρ of mudstone in Ref.-1 are between 1.32 and 2.60 g/cm3, and the dry density ρ of red mudstone like material synthesised in this study are between 1.88 and 2.02 g/cm3. The wave velocity v of mudstone in Ref.-1 are 1008.95–5008.13 m/s, and the wave velocity v of red mudstone like material synthesised in this study are 1225.03–1945.31 m/s. Moreover, the dry density ρ of the red mudstone–like materials is in the middle of the range of that of natural mudstone, and the wave velocity v of the red mudstone–like materials is in the smaller part of the range of that of natural mudstone. This proves that the red mudstone–like material synthesised in this study is a kind of mudstone in terms of physical properties.
The uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 of the red mudstone–like materials (Fig. 10c) is also in line with the classification of rock based on uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 of the International Society for Rock Mechanics (ISRM), the International Engineering Geology and Environment Association (IAEG), the British Standards Institution (BS),
23
 and with previous results from the Ref.-2 23. According to different classification standards, the red mudstone–like materials synthesised in this study belong to the classification of very weak, weak and moderate–weak rocks, with most of them belonging to the classification of weak rocks, which have greater uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 than that of clay. Moreover, the uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 of soft rock in Ref.-2 are between 5.61 and 34.22 MPa, and the uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 of red mudstone like materials synthesised in this study are between 6.26 and 13.41 MPa except that the sodium silicate content c

ss
 is 25g. It is proof that the red mudstone–like material synthesised in this study is a kind of weak mudstone in terms of mechanical properties.
The comparison of cohesion c and internal friction angle φ obtained by triaxial compression tests in this study with those of natural red mudstone
24–26
 is shown in Fig. 10d and e. Among them, the cohesion c of red mudstone in Ref.-3 and Ref.-4 are 0.87–3.04 MPa, and the cohesion c of red mudstone like material synthesised in this study are 0.93–2.89 MPa. The internal friction angle φ of red mudstone in Ref.-3, Ref.-4, and Ref.-5 are 7.01–47.83°, and the internal friction angle φ of red mudstone like material synthesised in this study are 28.76–45.31°. The cohesion c of red mudstone–like materials is relatively small, and the internal friction angle φ is relatively large. According to the dispersion of the distribution of test results, the influence of sodium silicate content c

ss
 on cohesion c and internal friction angle φ is greater than that of compression time t and vertical stress σ

v
. It is proof that the red mudstone–like material synthesised in this study is a kind of red mudstone with weak strength in terms of mechanical properties.
In summary, the red mudstone–like materials in this study are consistent with the natural rocks in terms of mineral composition, dry density ρ, wave velocity v, uniaxial compression strength σ

c
, cohesion c and internal fraction angle φ. This proves that the synthetic method of this kind of red mudstone–like materials is reasonable. The limitation of this method is that it can only synthesise red mudstone within a certain range of physical and mechanical properties. As shown in Fig. 10a, b, and c, the range of dry density ρ, wave velocity v and uniaxial compressive strength σ

c
 of red mudstone–like materials is smaller than that of natural red mudstone.

5
Conclusions
In this study, red mudstone–like materials were synthesised based on sodium silicate content c

ss
, compression time t and vertical stress σ

v
 with the aim of studying the physical and mechanical properties of soft rocks. The following are some major findings.
The synthetic red mudstone–like materials have similar physical and mechanical properties to those of natural red mudstone.
Sodium silicate content c

ss
 is one of the most important factors governing mechanical properties, such as internal friction angle φ, of the synthetic red mudstone–like materials.
The developed synthesis method could potentially be widely implemented in rock mechanics research.
